Academics.Review: I'm double majoring so I don't have many classes I can choose, also because I'm a freshmen so it's basically gen eds and core classes. It does get better as you get older though
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The Engineering programs at CMU do a really good job of having you work hard, learn a lot of things, and ultimately dressing you up so that top tier engineering companies can pick you up after you graduate. Though what you learn in class may not 100% relate to your career, the school does a very good job of preparing you to work hard for whatever career path you choose. Many offer a 5th year graduate degree to engineering students who maintain a 3.0 for there 4 year program (something that's not too difficult to do) and others looking for programs at other schools have a very good chance of getting in. That being said, the workload can be tough at times and many students have a bad semester or take some time off before figuring out a good balance for themselves. Ultimately, people rebound and become invaluable members of the workforce or research programs they join.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: People study hard here and professors can and will encourage it. It can be easy to get sucked into doing a lot of work, but by the end of everyone's 4 years, they have found the right balance of work vs. play for themselves. People are definitely academically driven to meet their goals
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: I felt the application program to get into engineering was straightforward. The essay was "Why engineering, and why our school?" which seems a practical question to ask. I felt admission was based mostly on academics and partially on outside activities.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I personally haven't started looking for jobs or internships yet, but several of my classmates were able to find positions as freshmen! CMU has great career services that can help refine resumes and prepare you for interviews as well.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: super strong in all fields of study
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The majors are hard but definitely worth it. It's a lot of work but it pays off. You are surrounded by people who all love to learn and are willing to do work, which is a great atmosphere. Many people participate in research and internships. Even as a freshman, it is very easy to find research by contacting professors and working in their labs. Many people get great internships with great pay, and the career center hosts many events to help people figure out what they want to do with their life and how they should get there.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The best. But LOTS of work.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Numerous career fairs and opportunities
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: You apply to CIT first and at the end of the first year declare. Biomedical is an additional major, and all you need is to declare that after you declare a first major. All you need to do is take the intro course.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Civil and Environmental Engineering and Biomedical Engineering have the best support staff. I thoroughly enjoy it because of the passion that everyone has and the opportunities. It has an average workload, and both departments are always showing internship/job opportunities
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Study is very rigorous. Workload is pretty heavy and you really have to manage your time properly to get everything done. Professors range from not caring at all to being pretty invested in your learning. TA's are a wild card--some don't care at all, and some are very willing to help.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It took me a while to discover that I was interested in the major but it was not too difficult to enter into it once I found it.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Eurhythmics is a very unique class that all music majors are required to take for 4 semesters. You cannot find that at any other school, It is really an awesome thing that the school does. The program is great and the teachers are really phenomenal, once you find the one that works best for you.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The academics are very rigorous and the teachers are almost always very supportive and open to giving one-on-one attention and help. Many of them act like your friends and you can tell they really do care about your success and work and that is uplifting.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I think that CMU has a great admission process. Their essay questions were not very unique but still stimulating. My program's audition process was nice. The faculty was very responsive to me before I had my audition about meeting with me for lessons and communication in general. The counselors were very helpful and responsive as well, especially thought the School of Music recruitment and enrollment.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I think the program I am in is very unique and useful for singers who will be performing. The acting training is absolutely necessary and the Movement and Dance training is something that definitely attracted me. It is a VERY rigorous curriculum, especially for your first four semesters, but I have loves all of my classes, even when taking 16 of them in one semester.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Chemical Engineering here is one of the best.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: TOP of the top, especially the Computer Science program. All the classes will push you hard, veeeeery hard, but you will learn a lot. Help is always available too. For my CS class, the average response time to a question posted on Piazza is 2 minutes, and we have 400+ students in this class (like 40-50 CAs).
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: TOP of the top, especially the Computer Science program. All the classes will push you hard, veeeeery hard, but you will learn a lot. Help is always available too. For my CS class, the average response time to a question posted on Piazza is 2 minutes, and we have 400+ students in this class (like 40-50 CAs).
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I think that, going into business, experience is a huge booster. If you have worked somewhere before as an intern, it'll set you apart from other candidates.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The Business School is still small, but a new building will be built to encompass more students. Professors are great, and the current building, though small, is very new, clean, and "professional looking".
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I had no difficulties getting into my major because all students are open to choosing their own major based on their interests.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Top notch. Professors interested in teaching.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Materials Science & Engineering is great for me because I'm a Biomedical Engineering double major. I don't like that you can't have BME as a standalone major. But, the research happening here and the faculty, especially in MSE, are some of the best in the world. There are so many opportunities for internships being in this program.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: CMU is great at getting you internships and helping you pay for your internship (through grants).
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The computer science program here is the best all over the U.S!!! And even non-cs students are excited to take computer courses!!! The atmosphere is so good here for learning something related to technology!
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I haven't yet explored many business courses yet. I would say freshman year is relaxing for business students.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: You apply specifically to the Business School in your CMU application and then get in or don't get in. Entrepreneurship is big at CMU along with analytical skills.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: It's nice to be a Business major because in your first semester you have a class with all the other business freshmen and only the other business freshmen so you get to know each other. You often share classes with these students so you almost always have friends in your classes. Internship opportunities on the East Coast or midwest are bountiful, but not many opportunities for the West Coast. Very analytical program
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: It's an opportunity to learn a lot.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The professors are really knowledgeable.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: CMU is prestigious for a reason. The academics are hard but extremely worth it.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: All freshmen in CIT (Carnegie Institute of Technology, CMU's college of engineering) come in undecided, even if you've stated a preference on your application. One thing I love is that freshmen in CIT have to take two intro to engineering courses (typically one in a discipline they are interested in and another one in a different discipline). I know a lot of people (including myself) who have actually realized that they are more interested in a different engineering field than the one originally planned for, which means that the two intro courses gives the perfect opportunity to explore your interests.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I'm only a freshman, so I don't know all of the details about my specific major (I'm going to be Electrical & Computer Engineering) but I can tell you that even the intro courses here teach you a lot. Specifically, in our Fundamentals of Programming & Computer Science course (15-112), people with even no prior programming experience at the beginning of the semester can make a fully functional game or application using Python by the end of the semester. From the beginning of the school year, even freshmen are encouraged to network with companies at the TOC and EOC (Technical Opportunities and Employment Opportunities conferences). Even though many companies are not searching for freshman interns, it is a great experience to practice networking.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: You can be any major you want and double with anything
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Though I have not yet had an internship while at CMU, I can say that internship and job prospects from this school are near unbeatable. Some of the most common recruiters are Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Dropbox, PNC Bank, Citi, and JP Morgan Chase. Most internships students get pay, and many pay well. As examples, a friend of mine made over $30 an hour at an internship this past summer, and one of my fraternity brothers recently turned down a job offer from Barclays. The school provides many recruitment conferences, and both administration and faculty share connections and opportunities to those who seek them.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I am an Economics and Statistics major, and my only complaint about the program is that the econ program seems more geared toward academia than business use. All majors that can be are heavily quantitative, which makes them strong, highly ranked, and appealing to employers. Workload across the board is much heavier than most other schools, whether you are majoring in business, engineering, computer science, or architecture. Facilities make use of the cutting edge technology that is often developed at CMU. This technical approach to education gives students the skills needed for the modern workplace, which is why CMU grads face among the highest internship and job prospects in the country.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Workload is overbearing but it's what everyone here signed up for. Teachers are great resources.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The best in the country in many areas. Students are really pushed.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Great profs, but lots of work
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I haven't had an internship at Carnegie Mellon but many of my friends have been Teaching Assistants for various courses. Those who have been TA's for psychology courses have had good experiences with both their instructors and the students. I know a lot of computer science TA's and they have mixed responses. There is a lot of work to grade in those classes. Due to time constraints I don't aim to apply for an internship before I graduate.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I originally applied to Carnegie Mellon's School of Art. I was required to submit a portfolio and though I could have done so online, I was recommended by a mentor to schedule an in-person portfolio review as well as an interview. I recommend doing this as well. Transferring within Carnegie Mellon was not a problem; I transferred into the psychology department near the end of my sophomore year.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review:
I went to a graduate program here called the Entertainment Technology Center, which focuses on exactly what you'd expect: video games, amusement parks, and anything multi-disciplinary. The quality of the education was extremely good, although there was (relatively) little instruction on the technical aspects of what you are working on; you're expected to know your stuff at this level before arrival.

The deep connections to "the industry" are probably even more valuable than the actual teaching. The ETC is arguably the premier program in this field, and it shows in the amount of interest from a plethora of companies who visit regularly for a variety of reasons.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Workload is extremely high and it can be very stressful. Some professors are amazing, some are bad, average is pretty good. Most want you to learn and are willing to help if you go to their office hours. registration is pretty easy, but may be hard to get into popular classes outside of your major.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Sometimes TAs grade completely differently which is annoying. Overall a good community in Tepper and everyone tries to help each other out. You really learn a lot here. Some employers don't recruit here, but a bunch of good ones do.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Given that I haven't finished my program, I can't say that I would 100% do it all over again, but I would definitely do what I already have over again. As a psychology major, people always question what I plan to do with a psychology degree. I would like to get into clinical psychology, and I think the research and course options available to students would definitely prepare them for success in the future.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I think the psychology program at CMU is pretty interesting. The professors are great, and they love to teach their courses. I am a psychology major planning to focus in developmental psychology. There is a lot of reading involved, and you will need to be familiar with certain theories and a lot of previous research done in your specific field.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review:
The workload here is heavy no matter what you're majoring in, though CS is really hard, you won't be slacking off in any school really. CS kids love what they do despite the rigor, same for the rest of the majors within cmu. The academic rigor is a part of the experience, and if you don't stay on top of things you can get overwhelmed fairly easily. 
The professors are great most of the time, but you have to communicate with them, even if they're not the best. Study groups are easily formed, but it's almost impossible to find a spot in Hunt library during finals week. I suggest looking for empty classrooms, you get your own blackboard to do problems, and never really have to worry about getting your spot stolen.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The Entertainment Technology Center is a world-class program for learning to make video games, themed attractions, museum exhibits, and tons of other fun stuff. The program itself is incredibly fun and engaging, although it takes a huge amount of work to complete. I wish I were still there!
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I went to a specialized, multi-disciplinary master's program, which was really excellent in terms of content and approach. It's hard to imagine another program which would have catapulted my career more completely.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I really love the opportunities that come with the IS program. The job opportunities are hot because we learn so much and learn to be such well rounded workers in the IS program.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: A typical internship is basically a precursor to what your real world full time job would be like upon graduation.  You will work approximately 8 hours a day (8am-4pm or 9am-5pm typically) and will ideally be tasked as if you were an entry level full time employee.  Depending on your home location, you may have to relocate (as did I) to where your job requires you to be or where the main headquarters are.  Most internships pay pretty well, significantly more than minimum wage (2-6 times more than minimum wage).  Internships are moderately competitive.  Having leadership roles such as being a teaching assistant (which I was appointed for a semester) or leadership in student organizations drastically increase your chances of getting an internship.  In addition, having a unique or highly demanded skill will also equally increase your chances.  For example, as an African American, I was offered an interview for the mere fact that I was conversant and savvy in Mandarin Chinese.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I haven't had one yet. But, i'm planning to have one soon. It is supposed to be a great experience.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The classes here are extremely difficult.  Not so much because of the material itself, because the tests are geared toward all the geniuses instead of the average kids.  251 is absolute hell.  Some professors are chill and others it's not even worth coming to class because you'll fall asleep they're so boring.  Learn to manage your workload and you'll survive, but don't expect the same GPA you had in HS.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: In neuroscience, the professors here are quite eminent within their respective fields, yet many of them still manage to care about the students on an individual basis--especially if you take a smaller class (seminars) with them. The research here is top-notch, both at CMU and at Pitt, whose neuroscience programs are joined together by the Center for the Neural Basis of Cognition.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: If you are interested in neuroscience, CMU has a large and diverse set of classes split between the Biology, Psychology, and Computer Science departments.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: As a biological sciences major, you spend the first two years as a chemistry major and then you take all your bio courses. The main difference between most schools and CMU with regards to the bio program is that we do not have labs associated with specific classes, it is the Really Big Class that you take once you have learned much of the theory in other classes. The workload is punishing at times, but well worth it at the end because there are unique opportunities to learn things you would be hard pressed to find anywhere else, such as building small molecule libraries or discovering new viruses. The professors and instructors are absolutely wonderful and take personal interest in the success of the students and will go out of their way to make sure they can do what they can to help you succeed.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The professors here are brilliant, most of them are here to teach instead of research. As such, they have a vested interest in the success of the students. The curriculum is top-notch, as a junior I am talking classes that most graduate students at other schools would not be able to take. The registration process works in a way wherein if you really try you can get into almost any class you want to take by the time you graduate. The workload, when all is said and done, will be overwhelming a lot of the time and is certainly not for everyone. If you manage to survive it, however, you will be able to work under any kind of deadline in the real world.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The great programs and majors come with very difficult classes. But in then end, you learn a lot of things. It's great.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Very challenging, but totally worth the blood sweat and tears.  The professors are very engaged and make classes fun.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I'm in computer science and totally satisfied.  Lots of cross disciplinary projects.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: After having been accepted into a number of colleges, I had this thought about CMU. I had not even looked at the school but suddenly wanted to go. All the deadlines were passing. Yet I put together a package, and was accepted. Big tip: Future students should always look at the classes on line, get to know the school and put that in their letters. It shows you care and not just sending out the same info to everyone. Also I did very well on the SAT's.. highly recommend if you need to, find time to get tutoring or take advantage of free (which I did) classes before taking test.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Love the school and feel as an Engineering major, will have many opportunities upon graduation. I plan to have a job set  up beforehand through my own process and with the help of professors, and other students. CMU has Apple, Microsoft, Google, among others on campus that we have access to. I'm loving my courses, and as an Electrical Engineer as a  major and computer science as mini major, will be able to enter the job market with great hope. I have no doubt CMU will and has to a certain extent prepared me for this. The counselors are top notch.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review:
The professors at my school are incredible.  All of my professors encourage students to ask questions during lectures, and they do not mind re-explaining a concept if their first explanation was unclear.  Office hours are always very helpful to clarify concepts.

In addition, Carnegie Mellon University's Academic Development program offers excellent resources to help students succeed in their classes.  Walk-in peer tutoring is available Sunday through Thursday from 8:30pm to 11:00pm in several subjects, which means that a student can receive help without an appointment from a fellow student who received an A in the course.  I have always found this program to be very helpful.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review:
I am a chemical engineering major, and I am greatly enjoying my experience.  

At the beginning of the introductory chemical engineering class, every student is assigned to a group with three other students.  The group members then works together to complete group homework assignments.  This is an excellent component to the class, because in the real world, chemical engineers very often work in project groups with people that they don't know, and the group members are expected to work together to solve a problem.

For every homework assignment, the "group leader" schedules group meetings, keeps the group on task, and settles any disagreements between group members.  He or she also writes the cover letter for the assignment, which summarizes how the group worked over the course of the week and how each member contributed to the assignment.  The position of "group leader" rotates each week so that all group members can experience the role. Furthermore, the groups are re-shuffled halfway through the semester so that students have the opportunity to work in a new group. This course improved my technical skills, teamwork skills, and communication skills.

In Thermodynamics, my second Chemical Engineering class, I appreciated that my professor was an excellent teacher.  His explanations were always clear and methodical, and he encouraged students to ask questions if they needed him to re-explain a concept.  Overall, I greatly enjoyed my experience in his class.

If I could, I would absolutely choose my major again.  My career goal is to work as a process development chemical engineer.  The Chemical Engineering Sophomore Seminar helped me to determine this career goal, and it helped me to understand all of the career resources at my disposal at Carnegie Mellon.  The Career and Professional Development Center is also a superb resource that helps students to improve their resume and interviewing skills, and obtain career guidance.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I never thought I would learn this much. the teachers are the best
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The Materials Science and Engineering program is very good. I want to get a PhD and work as a research engineer in renewable energy, and I have found a lot of very relavant courses here. My main beef with the program is that these relevant classes are exclusively upperclass courses, so as an underclassman struggling through sophomore year, I had no idea that I was going to get to take these great courses. The core couses in the program focus on metallurgy, which is not always relevant, but again, once you get through sophomore year you can start taking electives, and the program does have quite a few electives, making junior and senior year more interesting and relevant. I am very confident that I will get into grad school upon graduating from CMU, and if I wanted a job straight out of undergrad I know I could have doen that easily too.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: The engineering program is top notch here. I love every minute here, and enjoy the opportunities provided by a supportive staff.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Rough workload, but I'm learning more than I ever have before. If you can handle it, it's worth it.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Im very happy with my program, and if I chose all over again, I would probably choose it again. However, the job prospects for architecture aren't the best, so that is my only hesitation with truly committing to the major.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Many kids on campus get internships, and some at top companies like Boeing, google, microsoft, or qualcomm. It depends how proactive you are at reaching out and searching for internships, and what kind of connections you can make with people on campus who can help you out.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: As a violin performance Major, I am very impressed with the school of music. The violin faculty are truly the best of the best. Absolutely one of the strongest instrumental major in the college. The rest of the school is very academically focused, and everyone works very very hard. The school of music is no different: it's just as intense, stressful, and incredible.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The professors are scheduled so they teach the standard material well (which is not always true in some other elite universities) and are friendly, meaning that they will not shoo everyone away and isolate themselves in their research. The math/CS/Engineering departments are formidable without further say, but CFA's music performance majors also garner a lot of respect. There are plenty of study groups/opportunities advertised, and the library/other study areas (such as the Gates building) is a great place to study.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Chemical Engineers have it very good at this school. So many networking/job opportunities come due to the number of ChemE recruiters that come to this school. The teachers are great and our process optimization departments talk with the CS/math departments to give a very formidable research department. The only drawback might be the lack of a solid chemical background due to the smaller Chemistry department here.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I am an architecture student at CMU. My program is very demanding and I spend 15+ hours a week in studio. However, what keeps me going is the dedication the professors have to the subject matter and the deep level of which we study. There really is an interest to question the field and study far into the demands of the subject.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Music Performance – My acceptance to CMU relied heavily on my prepared audition for the instrument specific faculty. I applied for a specific studio. It was a very personal encounter. I had the opportunity to speak with one of the two professors and we talked about the expectations of the program and what I would be in for. The most important criteria is the ability to show you have fundamental material while displaying musical characteristics. Remember to take care of your essays. don't rush them, it's actually one of the most important parts of your entire application.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Strong Programs – At CMU, the academics are hard. No matter what program you are in, you will find difficult classes and challenges. But the professors are tops in their fields and really want to helps and get to know you.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I'm a mechE.  Apply to CIT, nothing really abnormal about it.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Most classes are good.  A lot of work but its not unreasonable.  Phys II is brutal
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Doesn't Get Better! Carnegie Mellon has a reputation for innovation for a reason. Its classes and staff makes it an awesome place to be, as well as the variety in the student body. Not only are 90 countries represented, but we have so many arts as well as engineering students.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Much Variety and Prestige – Almost anyone can find a major they are interested in. And at Carnegie Mellon, almost all of our programs are schools are ranked in the top ten nationally. My architecture program is selective, and I had to submit a portfolio of artwork along with my application. I also went for a portfolio review on campus in the spring. I found this a burden somewhat, but it did help me get a basis of art experience and I was able to meet the staff and professors of the architecture program before I was even admitted.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Design at CMU is absolutely incredible. You will not get a better design education anywhere else. The professors are so experienced with design and the field. They teach us what we need to be the most successful versus design graduates from other schools. You won't get the same design education from anywhere else. I was accepted to RISD and I still went to CMU. Just look at our alumni, plenty are working for Facebook, Twitter, Frog, Tumblr, Google, and Apple to name a few. The School of Design gives you the tools and resources you could ever hope for, and it will put you on top in the field. I would do it again if I could. I do not have any concerns for finding a job in the field because CMU prepares and its resources and skills almost guarantee and amazing job after graduation that isn't obtainable anywhere else.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Student of Design – CMU is the best school to go for Design. The workload is very intense, but definitely not possible. The professors totally reteach you what design really is, and you learn so much from them. I cannot begin to describe how much I learned from my professors, experiences, and fellow designers in my studio: you all end up growing off each other, and looking at the world and work in a different way. Internships and job opportunities are  emailed to me always daily, because plenty of companies and people are referred to Carnegie Mellon. All of the kids that graduated last year got jobs right out of school, and they are at huge companies like Pinterest, Twitter, Facebook, Apple, etc. CMU is the place for Design.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: If you are an engineering major and are striving for a 4.0, you will have minimum social life. Workload is there and is incredibly overwhelming. It's up to you to balance your social life against academics.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: The New Registration System Is Easy to Use! They new integrated registration system makes planning and registering a very easy task!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Amateur Professors – They have a host of British-trained professors, which is a problem since they don't TA while they are getting their PhD's. Their teaching skills are lackluster, and they have a very limited number of published papers. This is an issue if you want to go to grad school and need to get recommendations. However, there are a number of faculty that teach only one course, and these members are erudite and reachable.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Good Classes, Good Professors – I'm a psychology major and am pleased with the quality of the classes I am taking. There are a few requirements that I don't quite agree with, but overall the classes are interesting and the workload is manageable.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Industrial Design Major – I had an amazing time as learning Industrial Design at one of the oldest and most established programs around.  The first year you are in general design, combining Industrial and Communication (aka Graphic) Design to learn the fundamentals of Design.  From there you specialize into one of the two.  I found the projects to be very exciting and interesting, with lots of hands-on experience and one-on-one tutelage.  The major issue I had was that I had to do my own career searching (mostly), so it was rather difficult to get my first job.  However, now I hear things are alot better in that department.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: English Department Is Excellent – The English Department at CMU is outstanding. The professors are very knowledgeable and always have time to discuss matters with students. The program is difficult, but in a way that's meant to challenge you and get you to become more knowledgeable and be able to get a job after college.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Great CS – I love being a computer science major at CMU. The classes are some of the most challenging experiences I've had in my life, but they are definitely worth it in the end. It's a great feeling of accomplishment to make it through all of the academics, and realize how much you've actually done! I would not pick any other school to study computer science.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I came to CMU for the challenging academics and I found it. The classes are hard but you can always find help either from walk in tutoring in the freshman dorms or through Academic development or the professors or peers. It seems that there are so many opportunities to succeed you just need to take them.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Tough but Manageable – Academics here are tough, no doubt. All MCS course exams tend to be during the same week, so exam weeks are always awful. But most of the professors and TA's are great and hold regular office hours so there's always help if you need it.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Best Freshmen Internship Ever – I interned with Cirque du Soleil for four weeks after my freshmen year and will hopefully be going back after junior year for a three-month internship. The job was paid and I worked roughly 40 hours a week! It was the most incredible learning experience I could have asked for. This summer I am applying for a summer-stock job. Many Drama students work at summer-stock type places over the summers, and there are pretty much connections with alums or other current students everywhere you might want to apply.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors really know what they are talking about. So far, all the professors I've encountered have been very interesting, and are really engaged in their field.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Biomedical and Mechanical Engineering – This area of study has been very interesting so far. I am a freshmen, so I have been learning most of the basics, but all of my classes have been very challenging and engaging. Most classes early on are lectures with large numbers of students. There are weekly assignments, and a few group projects that allow you to interact with other students. Facilities are older, but very nice. Classes early on have guest speakers from all backgrounds, which gives great insight on fields where you as a student might want to pursue.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Striving for Success – I wanted to come to CMU because I would be able to pursue 2 degrees, one in Biology and the other in Viola Performance. However, this has been hard to accomplish due to the fact that many classes are only offered in one semester. For example in my year, Biochemistry was only offered in the spring semester so if you missed it one year, you would have to wait a whole another year to take the class before you could take it. And these are required classes. There are student help sessions for the more basic classes but as the classes get more advanced, the help sessions drop off. But this is countered by the fact that most of the classes are small and the professors are eager to help you and will work with you to find a time to meet with them.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Not Too Bad – Unless you are looking to get into Electrical&Computer Engineering, Computer Science or the School of Design it shouldn't be too bad! They want you to fulfill your dreams.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review:
Excellent Preparation for the Work of an Engineer – I am a Chemical Engineering student, and I greatly enjoyed my Introduction to Chemical Engineering class.

An excellent component of this class was the group-homework assignments, which randomly assigned all students into groups of four. With this group, you would complete all problem sets until the groups were re-shuffled part-way through the course.

The purpose of this group-work was to prepare us for the work of an engineer in the field, who often must work in groups with other engineers whom he or she has not met before. This component of the course helped me and my fellow group members to understand how to complete engineering assignments efficiently while still allowing all group members to contribute their ideas.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Teachers Care About You – The professors in the Physics department are funny and engaging, and are always looking to help out anyone in need. If you have a question, you don't feel threatened to ask. Also, if you are struggling, your teacher will try to help you out if you just ask for it.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academic experience is unlike anything else you could possibly experience. There is a lot of chance for interdisciplinary work outside of your field of study, as well as opportunities to study multiple things at once as an undergraduate. Courses are difficult, with a heavy work-load, but you will come out of this university at a level of excellence you never would have dreamed of.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I'm in Architecture at Carnegie Mellon. It is extremely challenging and time consuming. Our professors are very demanding. Though it is very rigorous, I feel that I am learning a lot and would highly recommend it for those who aren't afraid to work hard.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Good Professors – I'm an ECE major and it's definitely a hard workload.  The good part is that the professors are really smart and they can help you with a lot of stuff.  It's worth all the work because I feel like I'm really learning instead of going through the motions.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: No Regrets – I came in with the intention of majoring in Economics but declared in Economics and Statistics. I couldn't be more pleased with my choice. CMU has a phenomenal statistics program and the econ department has a wonderful faculty. They do a great job of integrating both subject matters. Ideally, I would like to work for the World Bank so I would have the opportunity to work with governments in developing countries. My only concern about finding a job in my field is that it is quite competitive.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The Work Is Worth It – CMU is notorious for its workload. The courses are always demanding but the final product always seems to be worth it. The professors and TAs do a great job of trying to help all students succeed in each course. Professors hold a ton of office hours, reply to e-mails in record time, etc. They really do want you to succeed.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: No Trouble – I have never had trouble finding an internship. My freshman year I went to a Hibachi place with some friends and ordered all the food in Japanese. A woman from another table came over and offered me a job as soon as I graduate (she assumed I was a senior but it was still pretty cool.)
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: You'll Live – The work here can be difficult and sometimes tedious, but very few people die from it. I have loved almost every professor that I have ever had here. There is a real genuine love of teaching and concern for the students that you sometimes miss at research oriented universities.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Easy to Decide and Flexible – When I applied for the school, I had to choose a specific college (Mellon College of Science). Once there, I did not have to decide on a major until my Sophomore year. To declare, all I had to do was talk to an advisor about my decision, about what classes I will need to take, and about future career goals. It is relatively easy to change majors within a college however it is far more difficult to change from one college to another.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Top-Of-The-Line Education – I am extremely satisfied with my education thus far at Carnegie Mellon U. With the exception of a few, my professors have been extremely helpful in and outside of the classroom. The wasn't a single question that they could not answer. The wide range of academic advising offered is excellent. Faculty at Carnegie Mellon are deeply rooted in research and their specific fields so it is virtually impossible to go a summer without either a research job or an internship for those who try.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Archies Are Always Hardworking – Yes, I enjoy it. It's hardwork at the studios but thats how the job is done. We all gather at times talking and enjoying our time together. We always work hard to finish the assignments given as well. It's really nice to have other people understand the work load.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: I found the workload to be hard to manage. With extra-curriculars and class, it was hard to balance, but some students did well. I think counselors should have checked in with students who did poorly to see how those poor grades can be lifted.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Unique Program – The Information Systems program is a tightly-knit community. The program leaves a lot of room for flexibility. It is very easy to add an additional major or just take classes outside of you major. It does require the Humanities and Social Sciences general education requirements, however.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Great Classes, Lots of Work – Most of the classes are really interesting and you learn a lot....if you can understand the professor.  If you can manage to pass the class, feel great cause it's probably one of the hardest versions of that class throughout many different colleges.  Also, expect at least 1.5 of work per night for the typical class...assuming you're not Architecture or Computer Science...or Design...or Engineering...then expect more.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: H&SS - H&Lessstress? Being a double major within the school of humanities and social sciences is kind of a double edged sword.  On the upside, we are H and Less Stress (CMU is kinda big on both acronyms and puns) so we don't have to deal with 30-hour problem sets or exotic computer science brain-teasers that tend to take up a lot of time.  On the downside, some professors like to pile on the work to compensate for that, and you'll hear all about how your post-graduation plans are a choice between Starbucks and The Coffee Bean.  It's best just to finish your papers, let it roll off your back, and then go out at night with your H&SS friends while they desperately finish problem sets.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Know What You Want Before Getting Here – Be prepared to be passionate about your studies when you get here because the workload will be intense.  You dive in to classes pretty quickly so switching majors can be at times quite difficult.  Don't expect to get by with minimal effort.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Faculty are very helpful and are very informative.  Availability at most times out of the classroom makes really nice when help is needed academically or there is a desire to talk about their experience in the field.  Professors really care about teaching students as best as possible and make it generally enjoyable to go to class.  All of this gently softens the rigorous academic load that is both exciting and challenging.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The Work Is Worth It – Carnegie Mellon prides itself in producing "blue-collar intellectuals", and in fact, they should. If you go to this school, you will find yourself working harder than you ever have before, and you WILL find yourself staying up until 5:00am some nights when your first class is at 9:00am. And as much as it seems to suck at the time, when the semester ends you will realize how much you've learned compared to some of your other friends at other schools and you will be happy for it. Professors are generally very caring toward their students and always happy to help, some even give you their cell phone numbers and will invite you to their house or to lunch. Likewise, your academic adviser, though may sometimes not advise well, will always be there when you need him/her. The only real complaint I have about Academics at CMU is sometimes CMU flaunts how interdisciplinary it is and though often times it really is, it's still hard to double major and minor in things should you major in an engineering discipline, computer science, drama, or some other CFA majors. Your major alone gives you so much work that you find it hard to take classes in other majors. So sometimes I do feel like the University is leaned too far into depth and not enough into breadth.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Work Hard, Party Harder – The architecture major is known to be one of the two most difficult majors at CMU (rivaling Computer Science). At all hours of the night, you will see the studio lights shining in the middle of campus. When I was a freshman, before classes began and the course load hit, whenever I would meet an upper-class student and would mention that I was an Archie, they would immediately give up trying to get to know me because they know they'd never see me again. Although we are one of the hardest working majors, we also party the hardest and are very close to everybody in our major, no matter the year.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Always Willing to Help – At Carnegie Mellon you can basically do whatever you want academic wise. The advisors will help you to find majors and minors that fit what you want to do in life and figure out what you need to do to achieve your goals. The professors are incredibly helpful and always available to meet with students to help them with assignments and understanding course material. The workload is heavy, but incredibly helpful in the end.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Expert Teachers, Intelligent Students – The academics at CMU are grueling, but manageable. You'll learn from professors who know their stuff and you'll be able to work with other bright, motivated students. The biggest problem with academics are that many of the TA's aren't good, but there are many other options for academic help if you're struggling. The general consensus is that if you leave Carnegie Mellon with above a 3.0 GA in engineering or computer science, you're guaranteed to find a decent job.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: CMU is a very unique place. There are numerous places to study (as so many CMU students spend the majority of their time doing just that), but the cold can discourage many from venturing anywhere but the closest places. The athletic facilities are Ok, the library is really only used to studying, and its really difficult to get a seat at most places around lunchtime in the UC
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a great college town if you know where to look. There's shopping, dining, recreation, parks, etc... but the weather usually shuts down most people's travel plans due to the sheer miserable-ness of getting anywhere. Anything you need to buy is easily within range, and there's pretty much something for everyone if you take time off studying and go explore!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I often like to go out to explore Pittsburgh, which is a beautiful city, with my friends and you get to know the place better and experience what life really is like for a college student. It's not too urban like downtown, but not too suburban. It is a very college town since many of our neighbors are other universities.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is nothing like the steel city it used to be. It's a very up and coming city with an excellent transportation system. There are all sorts of different areas you can go from Squirrel Hill and Shadyside right by campus, to the Strip District the opportunities are endless.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is an awesome city with hundreds of things to do all the time!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Don't listen to the CMU students that say Pittsburgh sucks. Once you leave the area surrounding Carnegie Mellon, the city opens itself up to you. It has a plethora of neighborhoods with great culture, amazing food, and an incredibly friendly community if you're willing to go outside of the Shadyside, Squirrel Hill, Oakland area. Pittsburgh is a city with a lot of heart and a lot of things to do if you push yourself to get off campus more. Steelers games, Penguins games, and even University of Pittsburgh games are fun to go to. Kennywood, The Strip District, Lawrenceville, Southside, and other districts have tons of things to do. Ontop of that, the music scene in Pittsburgh is as good as any other city its size, large bands often come through on tours for usually less than $20/ticket
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is actually a really nice city with a lot to do. It is home to 3 professional sports teams as well as University of Pittsburgh sports. The dining options are plentiful and diverse. Pittsburgh also hosts many shows and concerts and has some great museums with art, culture, and history.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The majority of people in Pittsburgh seem to be friendlier than people in other cities I've visited, such as NYC. The area surrounding campus is extremely safe, though it would still be wise to use the buddy system. CMU has a program called Safewalk in which volunteers will escort you back to your dorm if you don't feel safe somewhere and are lacking a walking partner. There are shopping opportunities available by bus, though they are generally more than 10 minutes away. Taking time to shop takes planning because of travel time and the unreliable bus schedule.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: everything you'd want in a small college city and more. pitt is right around the corner
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There's a lot of events going on off-campus, such as cultural events and concerts. Pittsburgh has a lot of college-aimed events as there's many universities in the area. Also, there's a lot of sports and parks and good eating places.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a wonderful city for college students
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a wonderful city that has a lot of nooks and cool places to explore. It does take a little effort to get around, but it's certainly worth exploring (especially the food in Pittsburgh!)
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There aren't a ton of athletic centers or green spaces, but it works. It's a small campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a pretty nice college town
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Lot of construction, so they're getting better. More and more recreational and athletic facilities are popping up.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Besides a few older buildings (with a lot of charm) that need a bit of renovation, the facilities are great.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh an awesome town besides the weather which is extraordinarily gray.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I do not usually use facilities, but they are useful if necessary
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Many traditions, such as painting the fence, exploring the roofs of buildings, and so many more than other schools do not have
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's a great city to settle in.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's pretty nice but not too exciting.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Mostly focus on academics, some days like carnival are very spirited.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Academic programs are amazing, music and drama too.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a very cultural city. There's many museums around and there's always a show, whether it be a ballet or an opera. Shopping is hard to access, in my opinion, coming from a large city like New York. There's many parks around and it's a good place to get a lot of walking. Many places are very hard to access without a car. There's no real mall to shop at. There's Walnut Street, with a little selection of stores, that is easy to access by walking or by bus. The Waterfront, which is an hour away, can be accessed by bus as well. Shopping in general seems to be a day trip without a car in Pittsburgh.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Pretty decent. We could use with some more tastier food, but otherwise, it's a really nice place.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: People gets easily accepted just about everywhere, and the best thing is, people are competitive but extremely willing to help (even if they are busy). People in CMU are also very positive.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus vice is great! This college really strives to support its students in any way possible. Slight downside is that CMU needs more music practice rooms.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus-provided transportation is very convenient and on-time. However, buses in Pittsburgh under Port Authority are rather unreliable sometimes. Transportation is covered under tuition with your ID. There are buses to the airport, which is nice, but the ride takes longer than my actual plane ride. For long distance transportation, there are Megabuses and Greyhound buses downtown.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The internet is generally super fast and there is an abundance of computer labs for students to work on. There are many clusters on campus and you can honestly survive without your own computer. The network is reliable and there is definitely wireless access. Printing is available in many places and I survived freshman year without a printer. The printing quota generally doesn't run out, as you have $40 and each page costs $.05. I had over $10 left over during my first semester.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The weather is generally always against you. It can look beautiful outside, but it will be -12 degrees. In the winter, the snow is very heavy, so invest in a pair of decent boots. The weather affects all the students' moods, I believe. The Cut is abandoned in the winter and in the spring, everyone is out playing. When the weather is bad, it's terrible. However, Pittsburgh can also have very nice weather in the spring, and Schenley Park is a wonderful place for a walk. Overall, I feel like Pittsburgh is a city of extremes when it comes to temperature.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It's cold and rainy a lot of the time here. It gets warm for finals week though.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Good availability of computing clusters.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: The weather here sucks in the winter. It rains and snows A LOT and CMU will never ever cancel class for snow even when all other area schools have.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Without a computer you can get by in pretty much all your classes unless you are a CS/ECE major. There are plenty of computers available to you 24 hours a day. The network is fast but a lot of times acts weird for a few minutes and the internet stops working. Wireless everywhere on campus. Don't need your own printer, quota is usually more than enough.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Even though Pittsburgh isn't as glamorous as some major cities, the cost of living here is great and there is a lot of culture. Some of the best professional sports teams in the world are here and there are lots of museums and other attractions that students have free access to. The city around the campus is very safe.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: school ID's are bus cards, but the city buses are always pretty late.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The printing system here is very high tech
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a wonderful and cultural environment with plenty to do. You just sometimes need to search for it,
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: For CMU students, it's free to take the bus:) Although the bus is never on time, it's still convenient.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I love the computer clusters all around the campus. However, the network doesn't seem the best as expected.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computer science program here is amazing! Even a non-cs major like me would like to take some computer classes.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus is not big but offering enough facilities.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I would expect more reliable WiFi at CMU. Computer labs are good and I've always been able to use a computer on campus when needed. Don't need a printer, plenty of printing quota. Printers do break down a surprising amount though, but there are plenty you can use
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Plenty of things to do, just often bad weather so you don't want to do anything and its hard to do anything without a car. A car would definitely be needed to take full advantage of everything the city has to offer
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: High costs of permits and few amount of spots make having a car more difficult than it should be
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The Wi-Fi stinks in some of the areas.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Some of the good stores are out of the way.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It gets to be way too cold to go out sometimes.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The bus drivers could be friendlier.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Bus is included and therefore feels free and is great.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: CMU gives students access to many necessary programs for free! Computers are abundant in common workspaces such as libraries on campus. Printers are easily accessible; you can send an item to be printed and it will remain on the queue to be printed for 6 hours! Wireless speeds could be a bit quicker (re-connecting to the wireless can take a couple minutes especially if you've just walked across campus) but overall are fantastic. You could sit anywhere on campus and have speedy wireless access.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The Gates Hillman Center for Computer Science and both major libraries (engineering & science library and Hunt Library) are all fantastic places to work. The UC is very populated during the daytime, due to the popular black chairs and abundance of eating options in there. There could be more workout facilities, but I believe the University Center (UC) is getting a renovation to include just that in.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Students share motivation to succeed academically
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: bus's could run on time
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is beautiful at night
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You have to pay so much money for it
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The city of Pittsburgh owns the streets which run through campus, and imposes parking fees on most if not all of them. It is not imperative to own a car to get around campus or Pittsburgh (as city buses are free with student ID), and having a car may be an convenience or burden depending on your needs and where you live. There are usually spots available, if not on the road in one of the parking garages. Permit costs plus city meters can become expensive.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh weather leads some out of town students to refer to it as "Shitsburgh". Summer feels like it extends into mid October, at which point there will be a week where Pittsburgh decides to go from 70 degrees to 30. Western Pennsylvania weather is very volatile, so there are times where it will literally go from 65 and sunny to 25, windy and snowing overnight. The winters are tough, especially on students from warmer climates. So bundle up, scurry between buildings, and/or 'penguin' (walk in a huddled group for shared warmth). Phipps Conservatory, the botanical gardens right next to campus which grant free admission with a student ID, are a nice escape from Pittsburgh weather and schoolwork during the winter, as it maintains temperatures around 70 degrees year round.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: CMU prides itself on keeping cutting edge technological standards and being a leader in modern innovation. Technology resources are frequently ranked the best in the country, and are the reason why so many of the academic programs are ranked similarly so. You will find technology at CMU you would never imagine. A good example is having a crowd blocking your way between classes because they are watching a robot built by graduate students pull apart an Oreo cookie.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is one of the most affordable cities in America. Free with student ID are most of the museums and similar attractions and public bus transport. Though clubbing in Pittsburgh is not huge, there is a substantial bar scene. Pittsburgh is largely a college town, so there are plenty of business geared toward giving college students things to do. Restaurants, bars, stores, and people especially surrounding Oakland (where UPitt and CMU are located) are very college student friendly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I don't know about on campus transportation but buses are fairly easy to use and are free.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: If you didn't have a computer it would be easy to get work done.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather is fine. I'm used to the cold. It is sometimes rainy for a while or grey, but other than that it's normal coming form New England.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great culture, food, music. Many museums, easy public transportation to shopping, shows, etc.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: CMU culture. You either like it or you don't like it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: UC and the library and some other buildings are pretty nice looking, but athletic centers are pretty bad.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's not horrible, but I definitely won't be staying after graduation.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I've heard it's bad, but I"m a Freshman and we can't have cars.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: the computer lab computers are slow and old and often get hung while in use
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: there isnt much to do off campus, mostly just decent restraunts
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It can be very cold some days, making the walk to classes somewhat difficult.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very few sunny days in Pittsburgh and most of them are in the summer when you aren't there. Cold for half the time you are in school, winter just lasts forever. Not as cold as some places, but still very cold.  Rain will just come out of nowhere
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh can have beautiful days in the beginning of September and late in the spring, but harsh cold weather is expected in the winter. The winter is very snowy, but that is a regular winter for the area, so don't expect to have many (if any) classes cancelled.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: facilities are top class, with all the resources at our finger tips. Can't ask for more. very satisfying...
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is not going to confuse anyone with cultural epicenters like NYC, SF, or Boston. But it's actually a remarkably enjoyable place to be, with plenty to keep busy with, minus many of the headaches that often occur in those more prominent cities I mentioned. If you are willing to get invested in professional sports, there are few cities which can match the 'burgh for universal enthusiasm. There's also plenty in terms of urban attractions like Museums and restaurants (excluding true fine dining) and parks which are large and wild, putting places like Central Park to shame.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: I really feel like Pittsburgers are generally just extremely friendly folks. This is what I noticed from coming from down south.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Pittsburgh weather has its beautiful days, but winter is pretty rough (almost no sun). Fall and spring are pretty great and moderate. You'll have maybe two awful weeks of heat and humidity in the summer, but otherwise tolerable even without AC.

Layers are key throughout the year. Bring an umbrella. You will need a coat.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The network is usually fairly reliable and fast, but printers break down often -- almost always when you need them most, it seems.  Clusters are usually accessible when needed, but everyone has a personal computer anyway.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are not many permits available, and for those without permits, it is nearly impossible to find a decent spot.  The alternative methods of transportation, Port Authority buses, are just as bad. Very unreliable.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pittsburg has a lot to offer in terms of neighboring campuses. You get to mingle with U Pitt, Ducuesne University, and others. Great party life if you can find the time to get out and meet people. You don't need to go too far; U Pitt is a bus stop away. Many clubs in CMU often closely collaborate with like clubs in nearby universities.  There are also many great eateries around, I usually go almost every weekend and there are many options.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The technology at CMU is really good. They have many computers with lots of different software, very fast and reliable internet, and very easy to learn interface with these technologies. However, I still recommend a personal computer and although I have never found the need for a personal printer, I do sometimes get frustrated at the public printers.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Public transportation is free with your CMU ID. The buses are rarely on time, but they do get you to wherever you would want to go around Pittsburgh. The buses don't run often on weekends which is when we would want to use them.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: My university is the only university in the US that has a bagpipe major. We have a great music program which includes this major. Often you hear bagpipes or other musical instruments being played on campus, it creates a nice symphony.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Athletic centers are present and accessible, but they are not very big. The varsity athletic area is rarely clean and about the size of my high school's. Most other university's I've been to have bigger, nicer facilities, but it is still good to have them there and they have racquets to play tennis, racquetball, and squash student's can rent for free.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Winters are cold.  Walking in the snow can be uncomfortable.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: As for Heinz College, the printing service is free; the computer has been removed and used virtual lab instead.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
There is certainly plenty of things to do in the Pittsburgh area.  First off Pittsburgh is the home of the Steelers, Penguins and Pirates.  So if you are into football, baseball or hockey, you may be interested in catching a few games.  The Carnegie Museum of Natural History is also right down the block from CMU.  

In regards to night life, station square is a popular spot as well as Oakland (by University of Pittsburgh), Shadyside and or downtown Pittsburgh.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Aside from a couple of times when the internet was down, network service has been reliable. Printing is certainly convenient in that there is a printing station within a 1-3 minute walk from anywhere on campus.  The computer labs are well equipped with all the software that is necessary for a student to complete his or her tasks.  I would say that having a laptop or personal computer is definitely the preferred option among students since it eliminates the need for students to always be on campus to progress in an assignment requiring a computer.  Having a laptop or personal computer gives the student the luxury of working from home.  This is especially valued when the weather is poor and it becomes cumbersome for a student to trek through snow and/or rain just to finish an assignment on campus.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh have something for everyone, which from campus you can get anywhere by bus. Whether you are into sports, museums, parks, shopping, nightlife, it has it all. There are also four other college campuses that are all fairly close to CMU.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is fun but CMU can sometimes have a lame night life.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Weather is pretty bad for the most part especially in the winter.  It's bearable, but can be a pain to walk in the morning which can lead you to skipping class.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a decent city.  Def take time to go explore it instead of getting caught up in the CMU bubble, if for nothing else but your own sanity.  Oakland has some good restaurants and Squirrel Hill, Southside and Waterfront have good stores.  Pirates games can be fun even though they suck.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Well what can I say, computers are abound.  They're generally in good shape and accessible.  Wireless networks are good for the most part, the printers constantly run out of paper or break down so I'd advise bringing your own.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: This research university has a widely tech savvy student body and definitely meets their needs.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is definitely a vibrant and active town.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Public transportation is good for the most part--sometimes buses run quite late, but you'll be able to get to most places in Pittsburgh without a problem.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It is cloudy and rains often in Pittsburgh all four seasons. Coming from Minnesota, the winter here is nothing.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There are lots of great museums and theaters nearby, and are free for students. This gets old after awhile, however. Also, Pittsburgh is quite a 'boring' city--there isn't much of a youth culture scene, and musical acts often skip Pittsburgh in favor of other East Coast cities.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There are tons of buses, however, they have a tendency to be late, so planning is really difficult. And the only time you get a taxi on time is basically during the weekdays before 8 pm.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a beautiful city that has everything you could ever want to have in a city, but you have to look for it. Things also tend to close on the early side.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Not all of the computer labs ("clusters") offer the latest and greatest (and cleanest,) but many are open 24 hours a day. As of March 2013, the cluster in the Arts building (which everyone has access to, located centrally on campus) has some of the fastest machines in the world, running Mac OS on a 27" monitor.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Solid weeks of sun in the early Fall and late Spring, but far too much gray during the rest of the year. When juggling four massive assignments while rain pours outside your window, it can sometimes be hard to stay optimistic.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
Take the bus! It will pretty much take you anywhere you want to go. 

You do not need a car in this city, in fact, leave it at home. Parking is always annoying and it seems like the meter maids are ALWAYS watching.  They will ticket you, and if you don't pay, they will put a boot on your car.

Free public transit is a perk of being a student. Take advantage of it!

Taxis are often rude and hard to come by. Prices are comparable with any big city. If you know you will need a ride, call a cab WAY in advance.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is unfortunately grey A LOT! In the winter, it can be a real downer, but then again - when the sun finally does come out, it can be the most beautiful weather anyone has ever seen. The spring in Pittsburgh is very lovely.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It rains during the fall and spring, and snows for months in the winter. But it's Pittsburgh, so what were you expecting? The summers are nice when it's clear and sunny, and people really get out and enjoy good weather when it comes around. Plus, the snow can be fun as it invites skiing, sledding, ice skating, and snowball fights.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Public transportation is free, but it isn't really reliable. The buses are supposedly always running, but sometimes, you stand and wait for 20 minutes for a single bus to show up. Other times, though, they're actually on time, and transportation is fine.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
It's often rainy or snowy, but classes are almost never cancelled (not even for MLK Day!)
When the hurricane hit last year, we trekked to class despite the 50mph wind and pummeling rains. 
Bring an umbrella - it'll be your best friend.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is terrible, not just on campus, but through out the city. You are better off leaving your car behind. You can get around easily with public transit.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The entire CMU campus is wireless, with the exception of some of the outlying apartments.  The speed is decent and pretty reliable, although when it goes down, everyone's in trouble as a large amount of schoolwork is online or requires online research.  There are several computer labs, some of which are always free (not holding classes) and some are teaching labs.  The labs contain a mix of Macs, Linux, and PCs.  There are printers scattered all over campus, most of them linked to the same wireless printer queue.  It is a good idea to bring your own computer, if not as a matter of necessity then as a matter of convenience.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The academics at CMU are exceptional.  By the time you finish and graduate, you should be prepared for almost anything in your major.  If you get a job right out of school (as opposed to going to grad school), it will probably seem easy compared to what you did at school.  One of the great things about CMU is that it encourages mixing science/computers with the arts.  It is not completely unusual to find someone majoring in computer science with a minor in drama.  The computer science program is one of the best in the world.  The arts program is a conservatory (think Juilliard).  If you had to pick one thing that CMU really has going for them, it would be their academic programs.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: CMU offers plenty to do and has a good amount of green space for being a "city school."  While the school offers a lot, it can be hard to actually do anything.
