There are often times when life on campus consists of everyone working all the time, including weekends.  It is not a rare sight to see the outside areas completely empty during the day (even on nice days), with the exception of the people trying to sell you things or get you to join their club.  It is possible to be involved in activities and hang out with friends, but if you're looking for a school where you can just have fun all the time, don't go to CMU (unless you find hours and hours of schoolwork fun).  CMU is a great school, don't be discouraged.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I came to this school mainly for the range in strong academic programs it has. Not only is it number two in Computer Programming, its engineering program is top 10 and it's Performing Arts program is also top of the country. It's nice to walk around campus and see all these programs represented within the student body. Carnegie is also great with job opportunities.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Carnegie has pretty nice facilities- except for the main gym. Most dorms don't have air conditioning but are livable. The library is very nice and a major hang out spot. And if you ever have time to explore you can find some very pretty green spaces and hidden hang out spots.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Most everything you need is in walking distance. However, if you don't want to walk you can take public busses which are completely paid for in your tuition. Some busses aren't very reliable though. There are also school shuttles that can take you to further subdivisions.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: CMU has tons of computing facilities, between clusters in the dorms, printers in the University Center, and convenient web stations where you can do what you need to do on the Internet for 15 minutes. The WiFi can be a little spotty, but it's not always bad. You still should have your own computer, but there are options if you don't.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I've only spent a semester at CMU, so I can't speak to the winter months to come. However, the fall wasn't too bad. It rained from time to time, but there wasn't any lightning or anything like that most of the time. The temperatures fluctuated, but if you can deal with that, you should be fine.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Overall quite good, lots of people and lots going on at campus. People are very nice, and mostly everyone is approachable. There are ton's of public areas for socialization / the university center is very nice and inviting.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: CMU is known for its Computer Science school. There's no need to say that the computers and technology at this school are very good. There's ton's of clusters (rooms of public computers) and most of them are up to date and very fast.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Everything about Carnegie Mellon has done nothing but support my chances to grow and succeed in my field of study. The college is truly student oriented and unlike any schools I know of.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It rains quite frequently in Pittsburgh, and the weather is rather cold compared to the Mid-Atlantic region.  However, if you have a good winter coat and an umbrella, it is not a large inconvenience.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: These are a wide variety of athletic opportunities available on campus.  The University Center has squash courts, a basketball court, and a swimming pool.  Additionally, there are two workout centers, a dance room that often holds free dance and exercise classes, and ping pong tables.  There are also six tennis courts outside of the University Center.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Students at Carnegie Mellon University have cutting-edge computer technology at their fingertips, no matter what they are majoring in.  Our computer clusters (labs) are scattered across almost every academic building on campus, and they are open 24/7.  They offer Windows, Mac, and Linux operating systems, and include the latest Adobe suite, cutting-edge math and design software, and so much more.  

Printers are available at every computer cluster, and are also scattered around academic buildings and the University Center.  Whenever I have needed to print a document, a printer has always been nearby.  There are black-and-white printers, color printers, and large, professional printers used to print posters.  Furthermore, there is a full FedEx Office store in the University Center that can handle even larger print jobs.  

The wireless network covers the entire campus, and is very reliable.  The campus is covered with hundreds of wireless routers that ensure that the wireless internet connection is fast.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: everywhere, many clusters, but hard to print cause often breaks
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: We have plenty of computer clusters with top-notch computers and very comfortable chairs. The clusters are sometimes taken for classes, and then you have to go find another one, but there will always be another one. They don't get crowded because mostly everyone brings their laptop to school or works from home. The printing system is good but a little bit unreliable sometimes. We only have a few color printers, but they're in central locations so that's not usually a problem. The wireless goes down for a few hours during the worst storms, but most of the time it works great. It's a good idea to have a printer just in case the printing system or the wireless is down that day, but you probably won't need it so a used one would suffice.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are plenty if parking spaces during the later hours in the day between 4pm onward, however in recent months Pittsburgh has installed parking meters which has greatly deterred the willingness to use the spaces on Margaret Morrison and Tech Streets. You often have to arrive at campus early in order to grab the limited spaces that there are in the peak hours of the day. A car is necessary unless you live far off campus, however Pittsburgh public transportation is often difficult and a car makes it easier tour around the city.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The students at CMU tend to be on the nerdy side- in a good way. Every single person has a particular thing that they are nerd-ily passionate about, be it designing video games, to biological research, to environmental programming. There's a very dynamic and diverse community that is always over-achieving. Be ready to get way more involved in classes, extracurricular clubs, and campus events than you could possibly imagine!
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Parking is expensive for students with a car. For visitors, there's some free parking, but the main parking is in a garage on campus where you have to pay.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Lot's of precipitation, but I don't mind much, being from Massachusetts. I haven't owned an umbrella once, but plan to go through a few nice rain jackets and get a good pair of boots.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Academic programs are all awesome. The social scene isn't the best, but there are always things to do on the weekends if you look. Better athletic facilities/gyms and dining services would be much appreciated.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: If you don't mind the blatantly bipolar weather, CMU is close to Pitt and also have enough areas to walk/get a 5-minute taxi ride to good places to eat and look around in. Most of the areas that are covered by the buses should be safe enough to ask around for directions/help/advice. Try the Carnegie Science Center if you have younger siblings, or Oakland if you need some off-time.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Your student ID doubles as a bus pass - the school pays for it for you. Pittsburgh busses pass by campus every 5-15 minutes making it easy to get down town and to other parts of the city, but they can be unreliable in the winter or at night. Also there has been talk of the city cutting routes in 2013 because of funding issues. Major cuts were slated for winter 2012 but they were postponed due to a grant.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: We have more computers per student than any other university.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather is about normal for the north Atlantic region.  It is very warm in the early fall and late spring, and gets very cold in the winter. Wear plenty of layers and you can never go wrong.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
Carnegie Mellon students receive free access to Pittsburgh's public bus system.  Buses drive by the campus very frequently, which makes this a convenient mode of transportation to all nearby neighborhoods, including downtown Pittsburgh.

A campus escort bus departs every half hour from 6:30pm to 6:30am to take students to nearby apartments and residences.  This allows upperclassmen to stay on campus at very late hours while ensuring them a safe ride home. The escort buses are incredibly punctual, and I have not had any problems.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: the weather is great at summer and I hope it continues the same at winter.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: 2 days off for the purposed of creativity, ingenuity, fun and partying
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Most of the buildings are nice. There are always random events going on in the UC
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: HAHAHA. our computers are the best. Bill Gates donated millions of dollars to the School of Computer science. we are clearly stacked with tech.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Its cold, rainy, sunny, hot... It really doesn't affect me but every sunny day is a party out on the Cut.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: THE BURGH – Coming from Miami, FL. The burgh has a whole lot to offer. There are several universities in the area, CMU PITT CHATHAM and DUQUESNE. plenty of college life around carnegie mellon. Downtown is great, awesome restaurants in market square. We have a world class symphony downtown, check it out, its real cheap for students. Things close early, this isnt NYC,LA, or Miami. Sports teams at CMU, hahahha non-existent. except for girls soccer, watch out for them, they're pretty damn good. and we have a good rugby team? our only DIV 2 organization. Shopping at the waterfront is great, only a short trip on bus from campus. Buses run really well, CMU students get a free bus pass.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great Labs All Around Campus – There are plenty of labs all around campus so if one is full there's a good chance you'll find another soon. A great plus is there are macs, windows and even linux labs. The printing quota per semester is pretty large. I think I've TRIED to use it all and failed. And there's wireless campus network availability almost everywhere on campus and in most of the dorms. And if you need tech support, there's almost always someone in the labs to help you out or a number you can call. No real complaints from me!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The cost of parking increases almost annually and the lots fill up really quickly. They're only free after 4pm(ish?) and weekends, and even then it's hard to find a spot.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: In the summer and early fall, Pittsburgh can be fairly hot and most of the dorms aren't air conditioned. Later in the winter, it can get very cold and snow often.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Plenty to Entertain – The Student Activities Board was great in letting the campus know what events were taking place, and there were plenty of events taking place whether they were concerts, plays, lectures, or late night movies in McConomy. There is definitely plenty to entertain whenever you feel so led to get out and enjoy yourself. Even just hanging out on Flagstaff Hill is enjoyable when the weather is right. Besides the happenings on campus, CMU students have access to so much in the city there really aren't very many excuses for being bored.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Sleepy College Town – Pittsburgh you would think has a lot to do around the area.  During the day, this is completely true, however Pittsburgh is a sleepy city.  Businesses including starbucks close around 8pm.  This doesn't make sense for a city that has several colleges in it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: High Rankings in Each Department – Although CMU is ranked above average when it comes to overall rankings, each department/school is ranked extremely high up, and sometimes students miss that simply because they only look at overall rankings. Small school and campus = more teacher attention. My adviser know my by name and my background as well as internship and past. Helpful advisers and a great and talented group of students to work with.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: A Good Amount – there are a lot of museums students can go for free with ID card, a lot of restaurants. Many sporting events that sometimes students can win or simply get free tickets to go watch. Some school organized activities. Definitely a good amount of parties.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: All Four Seasons in One Week – The weather at CMU is very hectic and at times you can experience all four seasons in one week.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh Has Lots to Offer – There are many things to do in Pittsburgh and it doesn't take too much looking to find something. There are always local concerts, quite a few museums, a huge library, the cultural district (which is great if you love seeing live plays), the Cathedral of Learning, the Phipps Conservatory, and you can always catch a football or baseball game as the stadiums are pretty accessible. Pittsburgh is abounding with things to do, see, and eat, so you could say there is never a dull moment here.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: In the spring and fall it's nice and warm and in the winter it is cold, just as you'd expect. But, if it's sunny an there's not a cloud in the sky on your way to class, don't expect that it won't be overcast and rainy when you leave it (and vice versa). When it's cold, it's very cold and when it rains, it pours, but it could change at any moment. It certainly keeps you on your toes, but as they say variety's the spice of life.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No a Lot of Sun – Pittsburgh has fewwer sunny days than most cities, but the temperature is actually pretty good for a majority of the year if you are used to the Mid-west.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: There is very little free street parking around Carnegie Mellon.  Many of the streets require that you have a resident parking sticker which you can get if you are living in an off-campus house.  The parking garage almost always has space but is a bit on the expensive side for college students.  Since the campus is in the city, it is best to make use of your student ID for unlimited bus rides.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It's not worth paying to park on campus so i park at my place and walk to class.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It rains a lot and snows sometimes.  Life goes on.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I like pittsburgh.  A lot of good places to eat and shop and Upitt is right next door.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Bipolar Printers – The computer clusters are pretty reliable. The only problem sometimes is some of the printers go haywire when you need them the most, but tech support is usually around campus to fix it in the shortest time possible.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Everything in Reach – All of the facilities at CMU are accessible at any time throughout the day or night. They are very organized and clean as well. The campus is very safe as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Rains a Lot – It rains a lot in Pittsburgh which is the only downfall. If it is not raining, then the weather is gloomy a lot of the times. However, it can be very nice in the summer and spring. Also, make sure to bring warm clothes!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Buses Baby! The public transportation (buses) are very convenient because there are many stops and it is free as long as you have your carnegie mellon id card. The only downfall is that due to the cut down of buses, buses run less frequently, but it is important to note that the wait times are not bad at all. Also, buses do not run from 2am to 6am: a minor inconvenience.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's Available, but Apparently Expensive. I don't bring my car to school because I hear getting a parking permit is really expensive.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: CMU has numerous computer clusters that are free at most times. Students are able to access some clusters 24/7. Different clusters usually support different systems. The clusters mostly get crowded on due dates for homework, but there are plenty of clusters, so you should be able to find a seat in one of them.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Buses Are Okay – The buses are usually pretty convenient. They run almost everywhere necessary, but more importantly, with your CMU ID, they are free. The down side is the buses are rarely on time, and it is most likely that you will have to wait for the buses to come.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: CMU campus is not exactly located in the Pittsburgh city (e.i. downtown or Oakland). However, Oakland (where U Pitt and various interesting places to visit are) is literally one bridge down and easy to access. Benefit of not being inside Oakland is we have a big beautiful campus without all the traffic and noise that U Pitt has.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: They Are Reliable and Reachable – They are a bit slow sometimes, but I think they are for the most part accessible enough. They have a good software suite and both PC and Mac, so I think it should suit everyone fine.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Dorms Get Cold/Hot – The dorms are very poorly maintained. At least once or twice, the dorms were unbearably cold during the winter, and for the first few weeks and the last few weeks of school, the heat is just sweltering. I went to high school in seasonal New Hampshire, and it was so bad as this in the dorms (I went to a boarding school).
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Terrible Library – The library at CMU is smaller than my high school library. I went to Phillips Exeter, where the library was one of the most renowned in the world, but CMU's library is absolutely dismal. There is hardly enough research material for anything, so we need to get things on an inter-library loan. I think this is a waste of valuable time for students!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Not a Big City but Plenty Stuffs Around – Pittsburgh is not a very big city but you have lots of stuff around to do and go about.CMU may not be a partying college but you would have lots of opportunities for free food and some parties here and there.Pretty helpful and cordial atmosphere out here.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
Impressive Network Speed. http://i.imgur.com/mtciq.png

^I regularly download 15 GB 1080p movies in less than half an hour at that speed.

Computing facilities are impressive. There are computer clusters everywhere. A personal computer is definitely needed here, though printers are unnecessary due to easily accessible printers at all academic buildings and the main UC center as well as some dorms.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great Technology – As a highly technical school, there were alot of new technologies to work with and to use to my advantage.  Additionally i believe the entire campus has wifi.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Absolutely Awesome – The network is great, and the administration strives to offer a plethora of software to every student
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: People say there isn't much to do here, but I have found plenty! Visiting all the museums at least once is completely worth it, since it is free with a CMU ID.  Plus there is ice skating in the winter and plenty of places to go shopping and such.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I Mean, It's Pittsburgh – If you try hard enough you can find stuff to do, but the nightlife isn't that great, and there isn't that much variety.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Never Dry – One major thing I've noticed is that Pittsburgh is rarely dry ever. It might not rain all the time and we might have our share of sunny days, but somehow it is always misting or the ground is soaked. I find it affecting my mood often.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Lots of Neighborhoods to Explore – Pittsburgh is a city of many neighborhoods/cultural districts. You can find a different vibe in almost every one.  The Strip, South Side, Oakland, Squirrel Hill, Bloomfield, Shadyside are just a few areas worth checking out. Because Pittsburgh is mainly a commuter city, the city center is a ghost town after 9PM, although it can be lively if you are there on a night during a sporting event (Pirates, Steelers, or Penguins).
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: So Pittsburgh is infamously cloudy and dreary. But before October and after March, the sun tends to come out more. Classes are pretty much guaranteed to never get canceled. You get used to the snow, but once the weather starts warming up, everyone spends all day outside.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I don't have a car, but my friends say that parking is very expensive. Parking is also limited. It's not really worth having a car, because it's cost isn't worth the convenience unless you're willing to pay. Buses are free with our ID cards.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Bus System – The buses at CMU are free with your ID card. The buses are great, except for the fact that they can be unreliable on showing up on time. I've gotten stranded at night because a bus never came: it's important to know when they stop running on certain days. They could be way more convenient, but it's nice to have them at all, especially since they're free, but they could be a lot better.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The wireless is great, very fast, and easily accessible. CMU is always updating technology, and there is no doubt about that-- one of CMU's largest majors is Computer Science, and there's nothing that technology can't do here. Only complaint are the printers around campus. They are almost never reliable. A personal printer would be the way to go if you have one, if it is an option.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: CS Is Awesome! Since everyone must take a programming class, the later options are many since all the CS classes are well-taught and interesting. Any non-major will draw great benefit from it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's very sunny and beautiful and then it hails. Or it snows wonderfully and then it's sunny and we get slush. Always bring on umbrella. When it is nice though, it's extremely nice.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: A Nerd's Haven – For all of it's competitiveness, Carnegie Mellon is a relatively laid back school. People are friendly and and there's an all-around happy atmosphere around the place. What's more, everyone is one type of nerd or another, so you can always find something to talk about with someone.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Great Technology – Computers everywhere, can virtually access a lot of programs from personal computers as well. Computers have a variety of useful programs. Most technical departments have their own clusters with specific software like AutoDesk for engineers.
Printers are easy to use, but need constant maintenance because they are used so frequently.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pretty and Practical – I love my campus. There are computer labs all over the place with printers that usually work. If you know where things are and how they work, then there are TONS of great technological things to use. you just have to make friends with people in all majors. the University Center has awesome workout facilities as well do many dorms in the school. the library is awesome with great variety and the campus is green. i am happy because it is like living in a country campus with a good sized town in my backyard.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I am a varsity athlete to access to athletics facilities is okay but after season it is hard to get into the weight room and the other workout rooms around campus sub par.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I Love This School; Perfect Balance – Everyone  is proud of their nerdiness. "Only at CMU" is thrown around a lot, but it's all in good humor. There is a lot of work, but the stress just makes us more crazy and appreciative when we let loose.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not Much to Do – There isnt really much to do but its not that bad of a city. There is the Waterfront and South Side Works to help get necessities and shop.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Fun, Comfortable Location – CMU is located in a convenient, (not-sketchy) area of Pittsburgh. Since we're right next to Pitt, there's a very college-town atmosphere. Oakland has some great places to eat. As a freshman, it's easy to walk places, but the good shopping requires bus transportation or someone with a car.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Expensive and Hard to Find – Parking permits are really freaking expensive. the only non permit parking is on Margaret Morrison but its really hard to find an open space.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Adequate Entertainment – Pittsburgh certainly has plenty to offer - sports teams, museums, restaurants. However accessibility is not great and the attractions get old quickly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great If You Like Cold – It can get very cold in the winter but the weather is very sporadic. It will be freezing one day then really nice the next
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's Very Nice – There is plenty to do, there are lots of food places near by. Having free busses is great since you can go anywhere you want.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: While there are parking lots and a structure, almost everywhere requires a permit or ticket to pay.  Street parking is minimal.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Small Town Feel for a Big City – CMU is surrounded by several different Pittsburgh neighborhoods, each with its own character and attractions.  The area around CMU is safe and people are mostly friendly.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Carnival, Greek Sing, Lunar Gala, free concerts, major networking
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not Very Good – Weather here sucks. Always cloudy, rainy, cold, or snowy. There are exceptions a few weeks during the year. When it's nice, it's really nice.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Wet. Warm, but wet. Sometimes snow doesn't even accumulate, it just slushes.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: No Complaints – Parking isn't necessarily free, but it's there and easy to get.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There is constantly a cloud cover that makes it very depressing. The weather often ruins outdoor activities, especially athletic practices. It makes it miserable to live off campus. Luckily the school and the city are both good about cleaning up inclement weather (snow/sleet/ice) pretty quickly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Working as a Cluster Consultant – I work as a cluster consultant so I see first hand all the problems we have. We have staff that is on call and ready to address any computer problems and most buildings are staffed from the early morning before classes begin to late at night. Materials rarely run out. WiFi service is great in most buildings and is faster than 3G on my phone.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Job Opportunities – Great career center, multiple employment opportunity conferences. It is very easy to get employed at Carnegie Mellon.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Computer Programs – Our computers have all the up-to-date programs we need for various classes, including minitab, excel 2011, and others.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: We have the 2nd most rainy days in the nation; At least Seattle has hipsters.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The gym sucks. the only good weight-room is the varsity one.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh Is Rainy – I personally love how variable Pittsburgh's weather is, but I'm also a native, so my favorability towards Pittsburgh is biased. One day it will be beautiful outside and then it will rain for two or three days. Pittsburgh is in a valley, so the weather is unpredictable because cold fronts and winds approach from different directions.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: CMU has good community facilities for students.  The library has a variety of quiet (and not-so-quiet) working spaces, so everyone can find a space that works for them.  Campus dining is not always the best, but there is a decent variety of options.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Parking is manageable and there are usually parking spaces available except within the city. There is a free parking street on campus called Margret Morrison street.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Its Mostly Cloudy – The weather is good, but would like to see sunny skies more
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is really no need for a car on campus. But parking is fairly reasonable
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The campus is great. it's well kept, and there are plenty of resources offered. I haven't had any problems with anything provided to me, whether it be studios or classrooms, etc. The only annoying thing that goes on are faulty printers... The workout rooms are all great, and campus activities are constant and there's always something to do.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh is a great city, and is definitely a college city. There's plenty of shops and places for college students to go to, and there's plenty of activities going on on campus all the time. Pittsburgh is the 3rd safest city for its size, but student's can't walk completely blinded wherever they go: use common sense. The students at CMU are very bright, and we don't fulfill the stereotype of a "nerd" school that most people give us. We have smart kids here, but everyone is sociable, and generally very nice.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Make of It What You Will – There is a lot to do in Pittsburgh if you have a car and know someone from Pittsburgh. Most students stay on campus and hate the weather, but there are many great outings to be had at Penguins hockey games, at the many art galleries and museums, parks, and local neighborhoods that make up the bulk of the city. The best way to experience Pittsburgh is through restaurants: check out dive bars on the South Side, get a steak on the North Shore, find delicacies in the Strip District (not a red-light district, but a marketplace), get some kosher pickles and bagels in Squirrel Hill or grab some Italian food in Bloomfield. Don't bet on the neighboring University of Pittsburgh to offer much in terms of social life or sports teams, as CMU students don't seem to spend much time in Oakland, but there is a lot to do down the street in terms of shopping or cheap food. (Lots of restaurants offer half price food after 11pm during the week; organizations make a habit of going). There are hundreds of opportunities to volunteer in Pittsburgh as well, but none are in very close proximity to campus. If you want to be adventurous, there is a lot to do, but you need to become very familiar with the area and public transportation.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Mostly Good – The library is nicely located, and there are two athletic centers--and definitely not enough gym space. The student center has everything, and hosts many campus activities. A lot of people are very involved and there are a lot to get involved in as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Theres Enough – Theres plenty of shuttles and buses to get around pittsburgh. You dont need take a bus to get from place to place on campus, its a small campus
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Should Be Obvious – CMU is mostly known for CS, so you would think the computers would be really good, but in general they're pretty old and slow. I've only used the Windows clusters, but most of those are XP and have crappy internet connections.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Getting Around Pittsburgh – CMU makes sure to provide fantastic opportunities for getting around Pittsburgh. CMU ID cards double as bus passes for a fee included in tuition. The buses go to all the nearby neighborhoods (Oakland, Shadyside, Squirrel Hill, The Waterfront, Downtown, The Strip District) and to farther destinations like the Pittsburgh Airport and nearby towns. CMU also has a shuttle service to bring students to nearby popular apartments and grocery stores on a very regular schedule. The only downsides are that occasionally the Pittsburgh bus system can be behind or unreliable, but not as often as people like to complain.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: During the summer, it rains sporadically, but when the sun is out, the weather is really nice. During winter, it snows and rains, but there are occasions when the sun comes out. Some of the buildings are interconnected, so once you're in the building, the weather doesn't really matter anymore. However, the walk to and from the academic buildings can be rather terrifying once the weather starts to get cold.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Awesome Research Opportunities and Meet Awesome People – Especially in the sciences and engineering, undergraduate research is highly valued and the people you meet will probably help you in the future for networking and what not. The faculty and students are insanely passionate about what they're doing and the philosophy that nothing is more beautiful than someone who loves what they do is held pretty strongly here.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pittsburgh Unique Culture – Pittsburgh is one of (if the the) most livable city in the USA. Cheap housing allows for more money to spend around the town. The big business draws of Pittsburgh are robotics, the medical fields, and the city is especially friendly to start-ups. The National Aviary, plenty of museums and libraries, and one of the world premiere glass art centers are just a couple gems which offer great opportunities for fun and learning. The sports scene is phenomenal, the central hub of some of the widest spread fan bases around. The personality of Pittsburgh's citizens ranges from savvy businessmen to youthful hipsters, but all people have friendly, folksy dispositions (and some of them even speak Pittsburghese). The weather can be a drag, with frigid winters, hot summers, and rain nearly half the year, but honestly it's a fair price to pay for a fantastic city.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Awesome Atmosphere – North and East of campus are pretty affluent neighborhoods which have plenty of things to do. South of campus, there are extensive hiking trails and west of campus is UPitt which has plenty of shops, attractions and places to visit. The whole city is a bus ride away and the whole campus is lit with activities.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: there is not a lot of parking. There is a parking garage, but this costs money, and there are meters, but that also costs money. Buses are a pretty good option for transportation.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Very well known school with many job and internship opportunities.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Literally just search professors within your desired field and ask to meet with them to talk about their work and job opportunities. They're very helpful.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Many students are given job/internship opportunities after graduating from CMU.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Recruiters are always on campus. Jobs are not given to you, but they are not hard to find. You just have to be persistent and determined. I have friends that have found internships every year they have been at CMU. We have top companies from every industry on campus and at career fairs as well. The alumni network is also very supportive. Many alumni come back to recruit and they are always trying to give CMU students an edge. The alumni network is a little small though compared with other top schools.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: CMU will get you a job. Every graduate that I know has multiple job offers and many are well above the average for their fields. It's not uncommon for a student to be picking from several 6 figure options.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The only thing CMU can boast is that their students will stick together and commiserate as productively as possible, including alumni. Some degrees have an easier time with job prospects, that's for sure, but overall having a piece of paper that says Carnegie Mellon University will help open some doors. Maybe its because people know by now that if you made it out of CMU, you're tough enough for the real world. Or maybe they pity us. As long as I get a job, I don't really care. We have a couple of big job fairs every year which invite big companies, as well as a few networking events. If you're looking for opportunities, you will eventually find them. These are usually student-planned events, not university-hosted, so they are actually executed well and with students' interests in mind.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Everyone knows the prestige that comes with the school name. Carnegie Mellon University is known for its renowned STEM and Fine Arts courses and all companies want to hire CMU students. There are a couple of career fairs each semester and a ton of employers come out specifically looking for CMU students. I think people could pay more attention to the humanities though, as those courses are slightly neglected and looked down on by others, despite being high quality.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I will get a great job. I am very confident.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: If you're in a technical field, getting internships is pretty easy. Tech companies love this school. Dunno what it's like for arts and humanities people.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: At first I didn't realize how big this school was but now I know that it's one of the best in the country. I know that this will give me the skills needed to succeed
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They're a little too good. They focus a lot on career building, even though as a freshman it's relatively difficult to find a job off-hand. I think everyone's a little too geared towards their careers.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There are job fairs that you can go to, the career center is very helpful, and if you look for opportunities anywhere on campus, you will find something that you are interested in.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The TOC is a really good place to get started on finding an internship or job. There are a ton of recruiters that come to the event and it is a good start for any freshman looking for an internship.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: If you seek them out, the job opportunities are there.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Every time I go in for interviews for internships, there's always a few of the other applicants who say something along the lines of "you go to Carnegie Mellon? Whoahhh…" I've never heard that with the applicants who go to Harvard or MIT. It makes me pretty uncomfortable, but it does goes to show the kind of reputation the school has.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Carnegie Mellon overall is top notch. Getting my degree from CMU will carry weight when it comes time to get a job. The internship programs are great, and Im looking forward to when my time will come. I will graduate from CMU with pride!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Companies love Carnegie Mellon students
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It's up to you to be proactive but the opportunities are there.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Though the amount of financial aid received wasn't amazing for me, the financial aid liasion assigned to me was indispensable with helping me navigate through the process the first time, and they're quick to notify you if there are any snafus with your application.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Very stingy first offer, but after getting a great offer from another very good school, CMU, while not matching my other offer, significantly increased my aid from what they were originally offering.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: There are literally only a hand-full of merit-based scholarships. I know many people who do not come to CMU because they do not get enough financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: CMU is an amazing school and if you work hard, you can pretty much get whatever job you want. Tesla, spaceX, microsoft, apple, etc... we have way more than enough opportunities for internships and jobs. If you graduate and work hard, you will get an amazing job at your pick of companies. And not just the CS majors (engineers, art students, CS students, and drama students tend to do very well)
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: You will get a job after graduating from Carnegie Mellon. You might not have to go to grad school, but you can definitely do that if you want, unless you get a great job offer. Employers know us and they love us. We have diligent and hard-working students that are hard to find elsewhere.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The schools provides enough money for you to attend without too many problems. Sometimes you get loans disbursed that you didn't apply for but a quick email will fix that right up. Grants are nice too because they really chop down a lot of tuition costs.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I got what i needed nothing more nothing less.....
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: For as much as this school costs, there is little financial aid available. There are no academic or athletic (Div. III) scholarships available.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: i wish they gave more money for aid than they did
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I have great aid but its still not quite as much as I need and getting in touch with the financial aid office is very difficult, especially from another time zone.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: No academic scholarships, but financial aid office did work with me to secure more money
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Carnegie Mellon doesn't have a TON of financial aid to give, but they do offer what they can. The school is expensive, but they do offer opportunities for scholarships to study abroad and expand your learning environment.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It is very rare to find someone from Carnegie Mellon who is unemployed.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I haven't known anyone to not get a job after graduating from CMU and I hear about alumni all over the news in many different fields (drama, music, science, design, etc).
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: They'll meet about 95% of your aid if your domestic
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Very good. Lots of opportunities.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They didn't meet my need 100% but they got close enough.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Although expensive, there is a really good return on the investment of coming to CMU.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial aid was very helpful at first. It is just recently that it has become a much more incurring issue than I expected.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I don't really know anything about scholarships specifically CMU.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Aid is pretty generous. I have more problems with the FAFSA itself than my school.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Straight foward. Need is met if you apply early decision.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: CMU doesn't offer international students ANY financial aids.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was given a lot of financial aid easily and they've always been helpful with my questions and problems.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I did not get as money as I would have liked but I am getting a lot out of the school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The process was pretty simple, I just had to apply for FAFSA and fill out a CSS application. It's difficult to earn a lot of financial aid unless you really need it, though. Student invoices and account activity is available on your online account for easy viewing, but you might have to wait a few days for updates to show.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: They do not give an appropriate amount of Financial aid. They continue to increase tuition costs, but do not increase financial aid. They take away what they promised for no reason. Such an expensive school needs to give more financial aid to middle class students
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I received twice the aid at CMU than I did from an Ivy League school I was also considering. The people in the office are very friendly too as long as you don't yell at them - even if you're stressed to the max because it's crazy expensive... Make sure everything is in on time too!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I know that CMU values it's students and the education it provides, but I (and I'm not alone when I say this) just don't feel as though they do everything they can to make sure that students can really afford the education of their dreams. I know it's a private institution and that they need to make money, but, more often than not, it just seems like our school has so much money and yet so many students (myself included) have to struggle each semester to scrape together enough money to continue our education. Now, I got an okay amount of financial assistance from my school and took out student loans, but my mother lost her job and I'm barely making enough to cover our groceries. I've been selling a bunch of  my stuff, but we still have just over $6000 that we need to pay before I can start school. I just feel like trying to get an education shouldn't be so painful.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Usually goes well just be aware of your situation because things can change quickly and you can easily get screwed.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They are rather stingy when it comes to giving aid. You really have to work to convince them and always always always talk to people in person.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The financial aid is very good but not as good compared to schools on the same level as CMU.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
Originally CMU gave a fair financial aid package but then one day without notice more then 15 thousand dollars/year of aid was no longer on the revised financial aid letter. 

When I contacted them, they said they had originally "messed up" the original package. But they changed and took away my aid after I paid my deposit and committed to CMU, after I withdrew my aid and applications to other schools. 

Bottom line, I thought I got a fair deal, and then when I committed to them, they took my money away and left me no option but to pay. Now I got loans racking up.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: cmu is terrible at giving money. i got some and lost it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I pay about 1/5 of the tuition because of financial aid and scholarships. Apply for anything you can and you will be able to afford it.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: For such a small endowment, CMU still gives good packages and grants. However, since the price of tuition is so high, I still ended up paying a pretty large sum, even though I received a lot of aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: One Big Hassle. The school's endowment is absolutely tiny compared to other schools of similar prestige, so don't expect too much grant money. There are also so many papers to fill out - it sometimes gets extremely annoying. But the financial aid office does answer questions pretty efficiently, which is good, because you'll have a lot of questions regarding your aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: CMU does not get as much donations as other big name schools. Also it is a relatively new and upcoming school in contrast to the Ivies who've been around since 1800s, and this implies more money spending into their R&D departments. Therefore students pay more and receive less overall.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: CMU is generous with US students, but it gives no financial aid to international students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received plenty of financial aid, without it I would not have attended CMU. It is a pricey school but what you get out of it is totally worth it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Money Is Confusing – The financial aid office is helpful as long as you go and know exactly what questions you need answered. Walk-ins during normal business hours are fine. Student Accounts are entirely managed online, and sometimes the way things are posted on top of each other in a list fashion makes it confusing to figure out how much money is available or what the student owes the school and for what reasons.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: This school is very expensive, and I am grateful for the financial aid I have received. CMU has a great system where you can submit for scholarships based off of scholarships received from competing schools. I received my scholarship in this manner.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Financial aid is a pain in the ass, but that's just how it is.The HUB is very helpful, and almost everyone gets SOME aid
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Awesome Result, Difficult Process – I got an amazing financial aid package from CMU, but dealing with the HUB is always a pain in the butt. But, it's definitely worth the work.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Need-based governmental aid seems to be the only source of financial aid.  CMU offers merit-based aid only to a very small percentage of students.  If you're CFA, CIT or HSS, forget it.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: CMU makes itself affordable, but definitely not cheap.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
Yay Money! CMU has continually met my need when it came to financial aid. They don't give out many scholarships, but they give a bunch of grants. Every year I submit the FAFSA and a few other forms, and I'm good to go. 
The best advice for incoming freshman is to know that CMU offers "competitive aid" which means that after you are admitted, you can turn in a the aid package that you receive from another comparable school (assuming that it's better than the one CMU gave you), and CMU will increase your aid award. 
I got an extra $5000 per semester from CMU by doing this.
Value.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: What sucks is the lack of dining halls. The food plan is used at different vendors on campus, and it's difficult to find a spot to eat once you have your food. The two best places to eat are The Exchange at Posner Hall and Tartan Express, a recently added, school-sponsored food truck.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I love the food around the area as there are many different options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is typically greasy and not my favorite.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Deluca's and Pamela's are by far the best two diners I've been to in my entire life. Those two places alone make Pittsburgh's food rating five stars for me. 

Pamela's for pancakes and home fries. Deluca's for omelettes and breakfast burritos.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review:
On campus dining options have gotten considerably better over the last few years. While late night options aren't great (I hate Skibo Cafe with a passion, and Resnik Cafe isn't good either) there is now a pretty good selection of places to get a tasty, relatively healthy meal during the day. El Gallo de Oro is certainly not Chipotle, but it's bowls and burritos do the job. You can never go wrong with a sandwich for breakfast or lunch at The Exchange and the comfort food section of Resnik offers something different every night, sometimes very good. 

You definitely get more value out of putting as much money as you can toward Dinex and as little as possible on blocks. After your freshman year, use exclusively Dinex.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: My freshman year I did not explore Pittsburgh very much, however my second year I've gone to new restaurants almost every weekend and have been shocked by the quality of the food. Best restaurants are Burgatory, BRGR, The Yard, Meat and Potatoes, Hyde Park Prime Steakhouse, Union Grill and several others.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Despite there being many options, none of them ever change what they have, so even if you try to change it up, it's pretty easy to get tired of the food. The hardest thing to find is a variety of healthy options. If you don't care about eating healthy, the options are actually pretty good.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You may have to go a little far, but we have UPitt right next to us, which has tons of restaurants around. Each section of pittsburgh has tons of cuisine, it just may take a while to get there.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: First off, the staff is amazing! They're so nice and friendly and the school is always trying to change things up. Overall the food quality is ok, but being vegetarian on campus is manageable but sometimes depressing. Many things are cooked on meat-laden surfaces, and you can forget eating most things cooked on a grill. The meal plans are a complete scam, get off them as quickly as possible. CMU's dining style is untraditional- instead of a huge dining hall they have a lot of little places around campus like restaurants that all serve different types of food. Culinart is OK as a food provider, although the quality can vary depending on the day. It's good when you learn what restaurants work for you. But in reality, when the winter hits, everyone just goes to the closest food because it's easiest.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I like the variety and there's a lot of choices, but sometimes the lines are very long, especially in the UC because it's lunchtime and everyone is trying to grab food before their next class.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Craig Street is the closest and you can get there by walking and then there's Squirrel Hill which you need to take a bus to (except the bus is free for students!). The variety is nice, but there's a lot of Asian places and there's a strong Jewish presence in the community so there's a lot of kosher restaurants.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It was prerry consistently bad, i ate out like allllll the time
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: No variety, and the better options are closer to Pitt.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: What college doesn't love Chipotle? There's at least two within an easy walk or bus ride away. There's a lot of great local Pittburgh eats such as Pirmanti Brother's and a lot of great places in Schenely Plaza including Waffelonia which is a must eat!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: People complain that it's awful but honestly I've been to other schools around the state and our food is not THAT BAD. It gets old because you will pick favorites and only go there and then get tired of your favorites but it's fine
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the off campus dining because it's very cheap considering how good it is. There is a spot on Craig street called LuLus (it's Asian fusion) and it's fantastic and super cheap. They also deliver to the dorms so eat it all the time to be honest. Pittsburgh is also a lot larger than people expect so you will never run out of choices!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food quality for campus dining could definitely be better but there are some really good options for getting the most out of your meal plan. I'd consider only buying food at  The Exchange, Tazza d'Oro, and Resnik Cafe to get the best and most food for your meal blocks.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Sometimes you'll have to travel a little bit further, but there is really good food in Pittsburgh
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Many options to eat off campus. There is anywhere from fast food to ethnic cuisine. Some places have student discounts as well.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are  easily accessible areas both within walking distance and 5 minutes away by bus. There's a variety of cuisines, from Middle Eastern to Asian to American. There exist three places off campus where your dinex (CMU meal cash) can be used: Vocelli's, Subway, and Eat n' Park. The prices elsewhere range from affordable to pricey, depending on what sort of food and occasion you're looking to find a place for. Overall, you're likely to find whatever you want within a reasonable distance.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's not worth your money, but you have to be on a meal plan freshman year. However, improvements have been made from last year.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pittsburgh is full of great dining options, and CMU is constantly coming out with apps and deals to get food delivered on campus from outside restaurants.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I love a couple spots but I rarely eat off campus
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pittsburgh has a lot of very good, very affordable food options
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Like everything else, it's vastly improving.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: So many options and affordable.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Somewhat of a range, not very healthy at all.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Gets really old, REALLY fast!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Noodles and Company is a really satisfying restaurant near campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pittsburgh has great food. I really enjoy eating off-campus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: As far as eating healthily and for a good price, there really is no place that is good for both, excepting The Exchange.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Lots of variety, pretty good. Kinda expensive.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is no official dining hall. There's little cafes around campus. I feel like the meal plan is generally a big rip off. It's cheaper to pay by cash, in my opinion, because for me, one meal is not worth $10-$11. There is a wide selection, with options like sushi, stir fry, and Indian. However, I find that options at the Underground, Skibo, and the CM Cafe are very unhealthy. I like how they have a small World of Cultures cafe where they change the culture being featured each week. However, the food might not always be good (I definitely recommend the French food). The crepe place is my favorite. I feel like they're always good and the chefs are nice enough to let you replace any ingredients you don't enjoy. Dinex/flex dollars are the best part about the meal plan because you can spend it at La Prima and at Entropy. La Prima has awesome mocha lattes and pastries, but be warned that they usually run out by noon. Tazza d'Oro also has great pastries.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Could use with some more tastier places, but it's ok.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a lot of restaurants in the area. You can easily walk or take the bus to various neighborhoods in the area. There aren't a lot of student discounts. There is a lot of variety, from Italian to Asian to various fast food stores. Prices are generally fair for what you get in return. The best places to check out are definitely the restaurants on Murray, since the street never ends and there is a continuous selection of restaurants to choose from, from Pamela's to Green Pepper. There's even dessert places like Coldstone, Gaby et Jules (macarons), and Razzy Fresh (frozen yogurt). I love Razzy Fresh and I personally think it's one of the best froyo places I've been to, and I'm from the New York area, so that's saying a lot.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Can be a far walk to the option-full central Oakland. Craig St. is pretty close though.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: There're enough dining locations on campus and I think most of them taste okay!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are plenty of options all over Pittsburgh. There is a decent number that are in walking distance, but you can get bored of them soon enough. Since the weather is usually bad, walking to them can be annoying and not fun. Decent diversity and many different ethnic options especially if you go farther out
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It would be nice to have more options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Pittsburgh is a great city where you have a lot of options of food.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Make your own food when possible.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Pittsburgh is a foodie city
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pittsburgh is a larger city with many distinct neighborhoods offering a range of dining. Most types of food can be found at reasonable prices, and many restaurants offer students discounts. I personally have dined at, and been happy with, at least one Vietnamese, Indian, Italian, American, Japanese restaurant.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: People who complain about campus dining tend to be ungrounded. The food on campus is very good for a college. Meal plans operate on blocks, which get you an entree, drink and side or two depending on time of day. There are no dining halls; instead there are a wide range of restaurant type eateries at which you can use your meal plan. From Indian to Mexican, Italian, and Chinese, almost any type of food is available and the quality is more than satisfying.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a few places to eat about a 15-min walk from the edge of campus, but the better places are if you take a 10 minute bus ride to Squirrel Hill. I haven't heard of any student discounts, but you can use your flex money at Subway. There's a lot of Chinese and Thai restaurants around.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's hard to find healthy things to eat on campus. Most of the dining halls close before midnight so a late-night snack is hard to find. Skibo Cafe in the UC is the latest and it's open most nights until 2am. Meal plans are a waste of money; it's much better to go grocery shopping and cook your own meals.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a decent variety of options spread throughout campus, with average college foods or ethnic, vegan, and vegetarian options.  Some of the locations are open later than others, making it possible to get food later in the night.  The meal plans required for freshman are a bit too large, causing many of the allotted number of meal blocks, which expire at the end of a 2-week period, to be wasted.  Some eating locations take a very long to prepare food, sometimes making it hard to have enough time to eat between classes or before sports practice/club meetings.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are many spots with a variety of eating options not too far from campus.  Some are a little bit far to reach by walking, but the free city bus transportation is free with a CMU ID, so these places are always reachable.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a few nearby options.  Craig street is dependable, but you have to go farther afield to find other good places to eat.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Dining in Squirrel Hill, Shadyside, and Oakland offers a pretty good range of options. The national chains are represented, but there are also plenty of local gems to find, mostly without secret hipster handshakes and the like. Primanti's on Forbes is a must, as it's the local place that we Pittsburghers identify with the most.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: I do not eat out much, but South Craig street is lined with restaurants. I feel like there is enough variety to keep things interesting. There are also many restaurants down Forbes Avenue. You can use flex dollars at Eat n Park, Subway, and for Vocelli Pizza.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are so many options all over Pittsburgh and they're so easy to get to with all the transportation.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Since there are a couple other colleges around, as well as some nice shopping areas there are a variety of options that have a wide price range, from $5 large pizzas to places that are have gourmet food.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The food at Carnegie Mellon is honestly, on the whole, not great. Meal plans are really expensive, and many students find they have a surplus of meal blocks. In addition, food places such as The Underground and Skibo are always almost disappointing. Sometimes you can get a decent sandwich or salad in the UC.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food itself isn't that bad but there are limited options and it gets really old.  Good places are the Exchange, City Grill and Take Comfort.  "Gallo de Oro" sucks.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a handful of good places on Craig, Forbes and Murray.  Pretty much anything you're looking for but tend to be expensive.  Nice break from the monotonous on-campus food.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a lot of great places to eat outside of the immediate CMU neighborhood, but they take a bit longer to get to. Places like BRGR, Pf Changs, Casbah, and Buffalo Blues are all really popular, but require a car to get to. If you want to just stay near CMU, Walnut Street in Shadyside, Murray Ave in Squirrel Hill, and Craig Street in Oakland are all easily accesible by bus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Nothing is immediately close by. A collection of a dozen restaurants is located on Craig Street, about a ten-minute walk. Craig offers a variety of affordable places to eat, as well as a few sit-down places, which are great for first dates ("hey, let's go to this nearby restaurant that's nice but doesn't make it look like I'm trying too hard!") Walk another fifteen minutes and you'll get to Pitt, whose off-campus options offer everything you could ask for.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Pittsburgh is a city for foodies (there's not much else to do, anyway.) While it cannot compare to NYC, it's definitely more of a dining city than Philadelphia is. Most prices are decent, with cheaper cafes and more expensive restaurants.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is pretty much every kind of restaurant within walking distance of campus.  There's fast food, fancy restaurants, and cuisine of multiple nationalities.  Also, on weekend nights after 11 a lot of restaurants offer half price food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are many options for off-campus dining that is nearby.  A lot of places are close enough to walk to within 15 minutes (unless you like to walk at a stroll) and for those that are a little far for walking, you can just hop on the bus (if it comes on time).  There's  a frozen yogurt place called Razzy Fresh that is close enough to walk to, which is a big plus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are lots of places off-campus, particular in the Oakland area and Squirrel Hill. Oakland is especially convient and the cost ranges, but normally it isn't very expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Carnegie Mellon University has a very unique campus dining system.  Instead of dining halls, students will be greeted by an assortment of restaurants scattered around campus.  Each restaurant serves a different style of food, so there is a great deal of variety for students to choose from.  There is a cafe that serves soup and sandwiches, an American grill, a pizzeria,  a home-style comfort food restaurant, a vegetarian/vegan restaurant, a Sushi Bar, an Indian restaurant, a French crepe restaurant, an all-you-can eat buffet, and more!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Dining not bad, plenty of coices but you get tired of it
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food isn't bad at all by college standards. There is good variety of options all around campus.  I would've given a higher grade, but the meal plan seems like a scam.  One common complaint is that meal plans are bi-weekly, and they don't roll over. The biggest problem though, is that you can't get two meals in one block period.  So if you get hungry at 11am, and then 3pm, well, you're screwed. Also, guest passes are something ridiculously scarce like twice a semester. Basically, the rule means that even if you have 20 meals left in the last 3 days of the meal cycle, you can still use 4 max a day (12) , and the rest of your money is blown to smithereens. This isn't uncommon.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: The dining plan is the biggest scam since bottled water! If you're a freshman, you have to use it (you don't really have a way to make your own food). Get the lowest number of "blocks", and more dine-x. The food is not bad, but it's not particularity healthy. However, there are a good number of options on campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are some restaurants near by on Craig Street, but for really good food you have to venture downtown which is a good 15-20 min bus ride away. There are some cheaper chains near the University of Pittsburgh campus which is a 15 min walk/5 min bus ride away, but just things like Qdoba, Chipotle, Noodles & Co.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are plenty of options.  A lot of restaurants in Oakland offer halfprice in the late evenings.  Pittsburgh is known for unhealthy food though.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The serving size decreases every year. The food is very unhealthy and can take some adjusting to (read upset stomach). The biggest downside is the cost. To get a filling meal, you can expect to pay ~$10. It's really not worth it.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Good but Not Very Varied – The food is good but it gets old quickly. I feel like half the places on campus have pizza, and then there's only one sushi place. It takes a while to find everywhere you can go on campus. Also, some places are rarely open and only about three or four are open til 2 am. Only one 24/5 food cafe.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are so many cafes on CMU campus for enough of a variety. However, sometimes convenience wins out over quality and it is easier to go to the Underground every night and have the same thing than to try and get to any of the other places before they close. Still, the food is good though I wasn't a big fan of the meal plan, but that's just me.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Depends where you go.  Exchange is good for the most part.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: over and over it is resturants and not changing every day
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Different Areas – What makes off campus dining great is the fact that you are surrounded by different boroughs which offer different kinds of food. From Oakland, to Squirrel Hill, to Shadyside, there's a variety of restaurants at different price ranges. Many popular streets too are right near off campus housing.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: If you want to eat off campus, you most likely want to head into Oakland. It's five minutes max by bus and there are numerous quality places to eat.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I personally don't find the campus food that bad, but I'm also not a picky eater. I know a lot of students who think the food here is really unhealthy and that it doesn't taste that great. There's plenty of lunch options. The food for dinner can get boring though. I personally wouldn't stay on the meal plan for too long since it's super expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Much of Pittsburgh closes after 10 PM which is aggravating since so many students study well into the night and are left without food (unless you opt for greasy pizza).
However, the variety of food is acceptable. There are Thai, Sushi, Italian, Mediterranean, Indian, Chinese, Mexican, and so on all within close proximity, located in either Squirrel Hill or Oakland.
Rose Tea has the best bubble tea in the CMU area, but is not necessarily spectacular. Aladdins has delicious Middle Eastern food -- which means flavorful lamb. Cool Ice Taipei has an interesting Japanese dessert -- shaved ice -- which though delicious, are rather expensive at $7.
There is also Chipotle a bus ride away.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Take the Cheapest Plan – Don't bother with the meal blocks, take the plan that offers the lowest amount of blocks possible.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Good Places If You Look – Depending on where you go, the local food is either really good or really bad.  You have to try places to find the good ones, but there are quite a lot! And there is still plenty of fast food, too, if you're in a binge mood.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Options, but Not Close – There aren't very many options extremely close to campus, but if you're willing to walk for a bit or take a bus, there are some pretty good places. Razzy Fresh (fro-yo) is a favorite, and so are Pamela's and Orient Express.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Hit or Miss – On the rare occasion that the food being served at any given dining location resembles anything tasting good, it is extremely unhealthy. While this is generally true most of the time, with some searching, students can find healthy alternatives at a few great spots on campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: A lot of people complain about dining on campus. We have so many options to choose from since we don't have one centralized cafeteria. There are plenty of healthy and many unhealthy options on campus. Only complaint would be that all of the good placed to eat are closed on the weekends. The best places have to be The Exchange and La Prima.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: CMU has a lot of variety, but not really a lot of options. There are a lot of places to go, but after 10PM or on weekends, you're pretty limited. Additionally, for what you are paying the food is not that great at all. It's pretty expensive and not that healthy.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great Variety – The food off campus is great but a bit pricey. If you don't mind spending some extra money, then off campus is the way to go
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Good but Boring – The food on campus is pretty good for the first few weeks, then you just get bored of all the greasy food you have to eat. freshmen 15 here we come!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Craig Street Food – Craig Street has a lot of nice restaurants within walking distance of the university. You can get pretty much any type of food there. Little Asia is my personal favorite. You can get a lot of food for a relatively cheap price.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: While there is a large variety of foods, the quality and quantity is terrible. Everyone wants to get off the meal plan ASAP. The block system is rather rigid, I'm unable to eat twice on a block in the same time period.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Oakland and Shadyside – There are tons of restaurants to go to in oakland and shadyside which are both right near campus. There's lots of variety. You can find a good place to eat for all different occasions. My favorites are Pamela's for breakfast in Oakland, and Elbow Room for dinner in Shadyside.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: So Many Cheap/Good Options – you only have to walk down to Pitt or Shadyside, to find either cheap chain restaurants, or local 'delicacies'. The 'O', Quaker Steak, and the Elbow Room are places in Pitt or Shadyside, and are really good. It's mostly 'american' food, but there are Thai restuaratns, sushi, and other things in the immediate vicinity too
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Tons of Different Types – People say they get sick of CMU food but when compared to other schools, we eat like kings. we have tons of gourmet coffee and stuff, and sushi, indian food, you can get steak and stuff. si senor isn't the best quality, but other stuff is, like the vegetarian/vegan food, and pasta lunches.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Fastest service ever, Oriental Express. Food is good, price is fair.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Market District & Waterfront – Check out the market district for great grocery stores, also the water front has some fun restaurants. Like, Eat N Park, P.F. Chang's
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Pretty Nice – Easy to get fast delivery online (campusfood.com), prices are pretty standard and not too expensive, food is usually pretty quality.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Not Much Nearby – There are places to eat nearby if you're willing to walk a while, like Panera or Qdoba, but for nice restaurants, or any kind of Asian food that isn't LuLu's, you have to search for a while.
Food.Author: College Freshman
