Food.Review: Lots of Variety...At First – When you first get to CMU, you're overwhelmed by choices of eating venues, but as the semester wears on the food quality generally starts seeming worse and worse and you really do just get bored...but compared to other schools it's not bad.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Squirrel Hill – Squirrel Hill has a wide variety of cuisines. It's about a 10 minute ride by bus and has plenty of spaces to park. Rose Tea Cafe is one of the most popular Taiwanese restaurants around. There is also Silk Elephant, one of the best Thai restaurants in close distance. The restaurants are all kind of pricey, but they are a great change from the campus food that we usually get.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Coming to CMU, or almost any college in Pittsburgh, there is an awesome thing called half-price dining. Many restaurants will offer their food at half-price after a certain hour, but you will have to check ahead to see if the restaurant does this. Pittsburgh has many good restaurants and a wide variety of cuisines. Also, there are many of the big fast-food chain's like McDonald's, Subway, Chipotle, and Qdoba.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
Its Edible – Pittsburgh is notorious for bad food, but anything outside of what CMU has to offer is a breath of fresh air.

For quick early morning breakfast, Starbucks and Dunkin' Donuts (Pitt campus) are your best bets. For a good breakfast, try Pamela's Diner (the one shining star in a city of terrible overpriced food).

For lunch/dinner, try Eat Unique, Star of India, or maybe Subway if you want something quick.

For late night deliveries, CampusFood.com is a godsend.

For 24/7 food (that awkward moment between late night and early breakfast), god help you: the only options are 7-11 and McDonald's.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
The food at CMU is sick joke. Not much more that can be said about that.

The meal plan is mandatory freshman year, but after the first year most students drop the meal plan.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The great thing is, CMU has lots of different, "restaurant-style" eateries, so if you get tired of one place, you can eat at a different location. It's not like one central dining hall that gets old after a while, but one full semester of only-campus food can drive anyone nuts.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Monotonous and Sometimes Poor Quality – The food plan here is expensive (and required for all freshman). The staff are not the best, and the fruits and vegetables are not fresh. Try to get off the meal plan if you are a vegetarian or vegan, it will be the best decision you can make.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Pretty Good Actually – Most of the food here is pretty good.  The Exchange is the best, so are most of the places in the UC and Resnik.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Terrible. Disgusting. Fatty. High in calories. 

I want to become bulimic just to rid myself of that plague after swallowing its filth.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: OK Food – Great late night options, but the stuff a short walk away gets kind of old
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The food here is better than people make it sound.  Some is delicious, some isn't.  Get off the meal plan asap though, it's expensive and not worth it.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
Carnegie Mellon has a HUGE variety of dinning options. They have different dinning facilities in almost every undergraduate accedemic building. They places are very convienent, and the workers are extremely friendly (you can sometimes get something free from them). 

With that being said, the meals are VERY expensive. On average, a plate of chicken tenders is VERY expensive (about 9.50 w/o a drink or a side). For that kind of money, it is well worth it to just go to Giant Eagle and make your own food.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Plenty of Options – There are tons of restaurants nearby to campus that can reached by walking or by bus. Great selection of food for delivery as well.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Meal plan sucks – The food here is somewhat good and there are a lot of choices but that's offset by how much it costs.  It's insane
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Not bad but low value – The food doesn't taste bad, and there's a lot of variety as opposed to your typical cafeteria-style crap.  Only issue is that the food in no way measures up to the cost.  You get much better value off campus, hence why people drop the meal plan after freshman year.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Two Words: Primanti Bros. Primanti Brothers is my favorite restaurant. Ever.  It will become yours too.  Just ask for the #2 best seller (the #1 is beer) and you're set.  There are PLENTY of other places in Oakland to eat.  Dave and Andy's has THE BEST ice cream I have ever tasted.  Pittsburgh is a food-lover's dream.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Best to get off the mealplan after your freshman year, unless you are a lazy POS and money means nothing to you. And you have no standards of good food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Try Oakland – The area by UPitt's campus has lots of student-priced food, late-night options, etc.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Food Is Not That Great – meal plan required for freshmen. Food is okay if you have low standards, lots of unhealthy choices.... For first years there is no choice at all because you are required to buy meal plan and I remember I end up wasting them.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Average but Improving – There aren't always a ton of great options for eating but I have noticed some improvements. I think my favorite right now is Carnegie Cafe with breakfast all day
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: there is a lot of variety at CMU, tons of choices all around campus, and best of all they all taste great!
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Lots of Options – Unlike a lot of other college campuses that I visited Carnegie Mellon offers a wide variety of dining options. We don't have a standard dining hall that you eat every meal in, instead we have little dining areas on campus that offer a wide range of food from pizza to italian to sushi!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I've Always Been Satisfied – See Summary
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: New Dining Is Much Better Than Old – If you read reviews of CMU, you'll often find complaints about bad food. Fortunately, this year a new food company was hired, and the food improved tremendously. Instead of having one main cafeteria, we have many smaller eating places. Some are even run by restaurants in Pittsburgh. So basically, you can get restaurant quality food as part of your meal plan. There's also places that serve typical, greasy college food if that's what you want. The only downside of the meal plan is its cost.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It really depends on what dorm you end up in, some are right on campus (like Donner) and others are quite a trek (Rez on Fifth). Sizes and whether or not you have AC/kitchen/etc. also depends on where you end up living.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is rather expensive for the quality we get in return.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Depending on where you live will depend on your experience in Campus housing. Overall, CMU needs to renovate some of the older dorms and build more campus dorms as well. A lot of forms do not have AC and some have extremely small rooms, but they are in good, safe locations.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Based on what Carnegie Mellon University has to offer to its students, there are various perks. The catch is that the prices vary greatly depending on what you prefer.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: Housing at CMU, like any university, gives you what you give it. If you want your dorm to be your friend group, that can be done. If not, you can just keep your head down and enjoy your other friends.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: These shoeboxes they stacked in the 1600's aren't top-notch on any front. I've seen dorms at other schools with swimming pools and tennis courts, meanwhile ours boast being mouse-free for a full month! Keeping on-campus housing is simpler than renting off campus, but considering how limited and how terrible it is, some students (who have money, or rather, whose parents have money) can afford to live in houses and apartments off campus instead.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing is pretty pricey and some dorms aren't very clean or spacious. However everything is close to campus and I like having that convenience. I've had a generally positive experience concerning the resident community since people on my floor are very friendly and the RAs host great dorm or floor events.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's fine. The dorms I live on are pretty far from campus though. The upperclassman options that are closer also tend to be smaller so I guess it's a trade off.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's not bad in comparison to other colleges. Best freshman dorm is Donner not entirely because of the facilities but because of the social atmosphere
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are great people and the housing makes me feel like I live in a hotel.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus is fine. Best option as an upperclassmen: Webster or Fairfax. It's really not that far at all. Worst option: Morewood Gardens. (besides the close proximity to the Underground.) Not because it's not clean, but it doesn't have a kitchen, and the food on campus wears off once you're done with freshmen year.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The physical aspects of housing are good and convenient, but the social atmosphere tends to be a bit cliquey.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: My dorm is right next to campus. The rooms are spacious and I have built a great sense of belonging with the people in my building. The shared bathrooms could be more clean but otherwise, I love my dorm.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Best freshman dorm if Morewood for location and Mudge for space. Expect average amenities that are cleaned around once a week.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It wasn't anything special. I feel like it could have cost less though.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Donner house is great as a lot of freshman football players live there.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Donner is comfortable and convenient
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Mudge House is great and freshman dorms are generally very big.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The room are spacious and it's a chill place to live.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: They offer many different types of dorms in many different locations for the many different people on campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living off campus with and next door to a dozen of my friends was the best part of my experience at Carnegie Mellon. Many people were able to find great houses to share with their roommates for less money than it would cost to live in a cramped one bedroom apartment in most other cities. For anyone who wants to live close to campus, almost everyone who wants a place can find one that's at most a twenty minute walk or five minute drive to class. Many houses are directly across Forbes or down Beeler.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Most dorms are extremely conveniently located just a few minutes away from classes, on campus dining, and the library, and and I enjoyed living in Donner my freshman year. However, living off campus on Forbes my last three years was much, much better.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: There are some really nice apartments in Pittsburgh, but you have to be willing to pay. Otherwise, it will not be very nice. The cost of a nice place will be similar to having a single on campus at CMU.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off-campus Housing is there if you look for it, but because most people lose their place in the housing lottery, many choose not live off campus. In fact, on-campus housing is usually cheaper because you don't have to pay utilities which can be expensive in older houses that are closer to campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love my dorm. I love the people in my dorm. My best friends live right down the hall. My closest friends live in housing nearby. It's great.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I lived in an apartment for 3 years and i didnt die.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Carnegie Mellon highly discourages living off campus and does not really value or assist students who do, except for some financial aid exceptions.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The housing lottery is based on deposit date, so the early decision students all get first choice and go for Mudge with is a former mansion with a courtyard and Koi pond. All the campus housing is within a 5-10 min walk max to the farthest point on campus so any on campus housing is a great option. There are nice lounges, walk in tutoring Sunday-Thursday in your dorm and tons of activities offered within your floor, and your dorm both on and off campus throughout the year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in donner, one of the freshmen resident halls and it is easily the best options. The community is awesom, the rooms are the largest and the people are the best. Everyone goes for Mudge though because from the outside it is a lot prettier than the others however it's super far from campus and donner Is so central to campus that often times you find people in the other halls crashing in donner cause they don't feel like walking all the way home. Also donner is the most laid back dorm because we have a lot of sports players so everyone is much more chill than Mudge (all the ED computer science kids go there), so it seems more uptight based on my experience there. Also Mudge is pretty but you could end up in the basement and those rooms are awful! The worst hall by far is hamershlaug for guys (it's a cinder block of grossness) and morewood (the bathrooms are gross). That's the other thing, donner has REALLY nice bathrooms I was personally shocked when I saw them. Also stevers rooms are incredibly small so if that's what your ok with then it's great cause it has air conditioning which is rare, however you will only need it for two weeks! Anyway based off of visiting all the halls donner is definitely the best option (and no one knows so you will probably get it if it's your first choice!)
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's difficult to get. Usually very cheap but you are up against students from university of Pittsburgh so it's very difficult to get housing unless you know an upper classmen who will hand it down to you!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Definitely start searching early if you want off campus housing, but there are really good options available at a very marginal cost, especially if you split a house with a bunch of people. Houses and apartments may be a little run down compared to where you're coming from, but they're all pretty functional and nothing you wouldn't expect to find in the real world. It'll usually save you a little more money at the expense of proximity to the school. Expect to live in Shadyside, Oakland, or Squirrel Hill for good neighborhoods. Landlords tend to be mediocre at best, but are pretty okay if you can get ahold of them. Pittsburgh is very safe, I've never felt threatened anywhere
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Make great friends, pretty clean, spacious
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I have many friends who live off campus, and they all love it and would never consider moving back on. Living off campus is extremely affordable while still being in close proximity to campus for the most part. Even if you live a little far away from campus, there is most likely a bus stop right outside your door. Many students also choose to ride a bicycle.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The on campus housing options are nothing spectacular, but there seems to be a different type of living style for every student. The upperclass on campus options are much nicer than the freshman dorms. Regardless, living on campus is expensive, so many students move off campus after freshman year.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The proximity to classes is great. At most, on campus housing is 10 minutes away by foot. There are various options, such as group housing, singles, doubles, and triples, apartment-style housing, and some co-ed options. Some of the housing areas have exercise rooms and printers, which are extremely convenient. The cost is a little high when comparing to off-campus housing, but personally the convenience outweighs the cost difference.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Love living off campus. It's so much more spacious, easier to stay healthy due to having a full kitchen, and RAs are no longer a factor. It's a much better value than living on campus in a dorm.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most people end up moving off campus after freshman year because it is ultimately a better value to live off campus. The housing process gets easier as you get older if you decide to stay on campus. Stever has very small rooms, but is cleaned daily and has air conditioning, whereas dorms like Mudge are bigger rooms, and suite style bathrooms, and are cleaned weekly. Each dorm does, however, differ in cost.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: tons of options, not too expensive
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I loved living in my dorm because of the social-ness of it but it was way overpriced and cooking was a struggle.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live off campus and I love it, theres a bus stop right outside my house that takes me directly to campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms have a great sense of community and the RA's, housefellows, CA's, and mentors are all very accessible and helpful. They host events, such as Big Questions and Nostalgia Night. Some of the dorms have smaller rooms than others, but most are decent/average college-sized rooms. The best part is the convenience/closeness to campus (though some are further than others, like Fairfax).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: E-tower is the place to be!  Stever, mudge, and the suites on the hill are also very nice.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live on campus but there are a lot of options and it's very affordable
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Don't get into Hammerschlag or Scobell. All guys dorms, they get busted a lot and are not clean. I would say the suite style living is very nice. If you want apartment style, go with The Residence of Fifth but know that it's a little farther walk to classes.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: During my first year my dorm was pretty decent--there was a lot of emphasis on house bonding, and there would often be fun events to facilitate that.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Great communities but like any other college, enormously overpriced.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living off-campus is cheaper than on campus in most cases and more convenient than you'd think!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are many available off-campus places. People usually just fill-in where their graduating or moving friends have lived.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Each of the dorms provide a very different sort of environment. The cleanliness of a particular dorm is not up to par and should be dealt with much better. Besides that, most students are happy with the dorms. One of the best things about them is that they really are close to the buildings for the most part.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I am not participating in off-campus housing. However, I have tried and I feel as if it is a really complex process to find a place. Many places are very picky about who rents out their place. The area is generally safe and parking is rarely available. Cost can be high or low depending on what you find.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I think the dorms are pretty close to classes. However, many of the dorms are rather old and I think they could definitely use an update. The best options are definitely the apartment housing, since you do get a kitchen and you get more of an independent feel. The social atmosphere is nice. People are generally friendly and there is a sense of community in a dorm building. The cost, however, is rather expensive for what you get, since it isn't always clean and again, there should be rennovations done to improve the environment for the students. The housing process is rather easy. Amenities generally include gym and laundry.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The main hotspot is Beeler street, but there are a lot of other options.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: A lot of people move off campus because the cost of Pittsburgh is so low that living here after freshman year does not make sense at all unless your housing is paid for by a grant/scholarship. The amount you pay for housing here is NOT worth what you get. Morewood is the most convenient (closest to all classes and has a restaurant inside) but not the nicest dorm. Some dorms are nice but closer to Pitt than CMU so it's a bit of a walk in the winter.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are many options in the area, including many styles of apartments.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The community is nice and the dorms are close to class buildings.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Cost is ridiculously high and you often have to call maintenance, but most of the dorms are close to classes which is nice when the weather gets bad. Most have good sized rooms, but the apartment kitchens tend to me kind of bad
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It would be nice if it was more quiet.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus is great because it's very close to classes but living off campus is much cheaper and still close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living off campus is great and reasonable for campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: THe student life staff is the best.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are plenty of off campus options available. From apartments to houses, the surrounding neighborhoods of Oakland and Shadyside provide affordable living space, safety, proximity to campus, shopping and nightlife, and plenty of other college students around.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living off campus is a great option especially because it costs much less.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms are good for freshmen, but expensive and hard to get for upperclassmen.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: If you live in the Residence on Fifth, the only freshman apartment, life is great. The place is wonderful, spacious, and full of fine facilities. It has everything dorms do not have. It literally is the best freshman living space, hands down. The downside is that it is a ten minute walk from campus, and is a bit pricier than the dorms.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Easy to come across and way cheaper than most American cities (especially if you are living in a 3-5 bedroom apartment or HOUSE with friends - less so if you're on you're own). Be aware of different neighborhoods - there are many not FAR from campus but also not 5 min away. Housing stock varies, but most is very old - be alert to different levels of "involvement" from your potential landlord and be on the lookout for issues with the building that could be dangerous.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I live with my aunt.  Her apartment is about 15 minutes walking distance from campus.   It is a rather expensive apartment.  It would be out of reach for the average student.  If I could not live with her, I would live on campus.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: There are several neighborhoods available for the off-campus housing with reasonable price, around 400 to 800 per month.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review:
It was certainly enjoyable living on the CMU campus.  I believe living on campus allowed me to experience different cultures and backgrounds and helped me form unique groups of friends.  At CMU, I met people from all across the nation and from other parts of the globe.  

When I was a freshman, I did feel that my dorm in Hamerschlag Hall was quite small, but I still enjoyed the brotherhood of the guys on my floor.  As an incoming freshmen, I was at first concerned that I would want to live in a coed dorm, but living in an all male dorm turned out better than I expected.  In regards to pricing, I would say that the food on campus was certainly on the expensive side.  I would've been more satisfied with my dining experience at CMU had the prices been a little more favorable.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Each freshman dorm has its own pros and cons. But they are typically pretty good.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing is average.  A lot of people get bored with the on campus scene and move off.  Freshman dorms are some of the easiest connections you'll make unless you go greek so take advantage of it.  Only disadvantage is that people trash the bathrooms a lot which can get annoying.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: People love living off campus, but sometimes locations are hard to find. In addition, you have to be super strict when dealing with landlords, because not all of the houses are in great condition.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Lots available right near campus and downtown Pittsburgh
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I stayed in the dorms as  Freshman and Sophomore. I've had a both sharing a room with one, and sharing a room with four other guys. In the beginning I found this crucial as it helped keep me organized, having a touch academic schedule and in a new city, to be on campus. The are pleasant, I have no complaints. As a junior, now familiar with city, I am sharing an apartment with two other students, like having a kitchen and independence... yet I find myself mostly at school anyway.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorms all vary. Freshmen housing is all very convenient, with strong affiliations for the dorm you live in freshmen year. Upperclassmen housing varies in distance, but housing is guaranteed for four years. There is a strong feeling of community.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: As I am looking for off campus housing myself I hope to help you out. Seeing as we are located in the middle of downtown there isn't much available in the means of off campus living. Houses around the campus are usually grandfathered down to younger students. Apartments are much easier to find but a little further away. However, I believe they it is all worth it due to the fact that on campus housing costs so ridiculously much and I'd do anything for air conditioning, a full bed, and a kitchen.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
The freshman dorms in Boss House are excellent.  Rooms are organized in a suite style, so two double rooms and a single room share a private bathroom.  The bathrooms are cleaned weekly by facilities staff, which is very convenient.

The members of my floor quickly became a tight-knit group of friends.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are decent and the amenities are good. Each of the freshman dorms has its own personality and each one has positives and negatives. They are all pretty social, on varying degrees based on the personality and structure.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms can be pretty far from most of the academic buildings. A lot of the freshman dorms don't have ac but are overall pretty well maintained.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most of the freshmen dorms try hard to create a close community.  The RA's are good, and they have events by floor/building pretty frequently.  Also, most dorms have printing locations and workout facilities.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: Most dorms are old, not well kept, and overpriced compared to off campus options. The problem is, it is very difficult to get an off campus apartment that is close by, since CMU is a bit of ways outside downtown Pittsburgh. CMU really needs to build more dorms and renovate the existing ones, but Housing & Dining operations are not very well run here. As an upperclassmen, you have priority choice in dorms but many upperclassmen leave the campus housing system since options are poor.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The actual buildings are not very good, but the community within the dorms are amazing. Everyone that I have met loves their floor!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love the dorms on campus. I really appreciate that CMU doesn't make you move off campus like some other schools do. I've lived in dorms for all 4 years and the facilities are pretty nice and there's enough room that people don't really complain. Most of the dorms are super close to campus and you end up living amongst a lot of your friends.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review:
I was in Schlag, it sucked. I hear the the best is Donner, but everyone leaves out Boss, you get your own prime. Small cozy rooms, reasonable spot on campus.
Resnik is the best dorm ON campus. These suites are so damn awesome.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Pretty Decent Help – The off campus housing is extremely nice and available to even the sophomores.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: West Wing Is Where It's at – If you are fortunate enough to get into West Wing or Resnik, your college life at CMU will be much easier.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I moved off after freshman year.  I didn't think it was too hard to find a place for an ok price.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Depends on the dorm.  Some are old, some are new.   Stever is the most modern for freshman dorms, I moved off campus after freshman year.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Regardless of the dorm you pick, there are pros and cons. I live in Morewood E-Tower, which has the biggest rooms, a good house atmosphere, and a friendly maintenance staff who does a decent job of keeping common areas clean.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Not Bad – Some dorm rooms are really small, and not all are in the best of conditions, but most seem to have a really good sense of community, and dorm life actually isn't too bad!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Considering the Huge Student Body, Not Bad – CMU has a lot of students, and sometimes it gets to be too much for the Housing office because some students slip through the cracks and are forced, through no fault of their own, to move off-campus, which form my understanding is cheaper. While CMU is always adding new housing, it needs to work on the older buildings. Some of them are just barely liveable.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Lots of Apartments Throughout the City – There are lots of apartments throughout the city although a lot of the buildings are very old.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Readily Available – there are tons of different types of off-campus housing, it makes it easy to get a house from graduating friends or something. but you need to start looking like mid spring semester if you want to find something close to campus. the cost of living is pretty cheap in Pittsburgh, but it can get expensive for a college student, especially heating.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Apartments Are Easy to Find! It is very easy to find off campus housing. Many real estate and rental agents are available nearby and they are usually more than happy to help. Costs are low and these off campus houses are nearby.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorms are pretty nice. CMU offers a lot for their students, including multiple gyms, printers all around campus, building accessibility, etc. The school costs a lot, but you get what you pay for. The only thing I've seen wrong with the school is the price. Everything is offered to you: multiple opportunities for internships, jobs, clubs, etc. The housing process is simple. CMU's whole system of operation is simple for what I can remember. Definitely live off campus after freshman year, because it is so much cheaper.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Personally I'd Stay on Campus, but Most Disagree – The isn't much housing very near campus, and what is available is typically passed down so unless you know the owners, you won't get to live there next.  The other housing options are farther away and can get pricey, plus you kind of have to keep a car.  Living on campus is super convenient, but if you move off, you're not guaranteed housing if you decide to come back.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshman Dorms Are Great – The freshman dorms are incredibly convenient.  Laundry is free in the all-freshmen dorms (upperclassmen have to pay).  Many dorms also have practice rooms/pianos and computer clusters in the building (which is incredibly helpful when you're trying to use up your print quota).  Almost all of the dorms have dining and/or workout facilities either in the physical building or nearby.  After orientation, you really feel a special bond with the people in your house!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I currently live off campus and as much as I loved living in Donner my freshmen year, I like off campus housing much better. I have more privacy, a nice kitchen to cook in, and it's a lot cheaper than on campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Donner House Is the Place to Live – I lived in Donner my freshman year and it was the most wonderful experience I've ever had. The RAs were amazing, and I always had friends to hang out with. The community was outstanding and everyone loved living there. I had an excellent freshmen dorm experience.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Great If You Have the Right Mindset – Yes, it's freaking Carnegie Mellon it is awesome but you have to have the right mentality about being in college. In order to truly enjoy it you must make good grades and good nights. That means working hard and playing hard. Don't lock yourself in your room programming or in the studio constantly working on new designs and what not. Put the work in, get good grades then go out and get rid of some stress on the weekends (if you are really good at school, maybe even thi*&%# Thursdays or every night!).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: A Lot of Dorm Pride – I lived in donner last year.  The rooms were big and in pretty good shape and everyone really gets passionate about their dorm.  It's really fun especially during the first week.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
Dorm Life – SOme dorms and apartments are definately better than others. I was lucky enough to stay in Stever (which at the time was the newest freshman dorm) and I loved it! The huge lounge spaces were perfect for a social bug, like myself. My room in Stever was about half the size of my room at home....but it did not matter just because I was so busy, that I didn't use my dorm much ay way! 

My sophmore year I decided to live in an apartment which was about 2 blocks away. The apartment was not modern...at all. We had to buy countless extension cords just to power our laptops, phones TV's etc. However, I love the independence of having you own apartment. Simply knowing that on a cold sunday morning, to get something to eat is just walk out of the bedroom was freakin amazing!
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Cheap but kinda puts you out of the loop – Off-campus housing is dirt cheap compared to CMU's room and board charge.  It will save you a TON of money.  Only issue is that it's a bit harder to get in the social loop, but house parties become a big deal as you get older.  Know who to buy from though, landlords take advantage of naive college kids.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Small Dorms – The dorms are small, but this is to be expected of all the college housing, regardless of university.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Much Better Than on Campus – Housing in Pittsburgh is incredibly cheap, and it's relatively easy to find available spaces. Make sure to review your landlord first, since there are some real scumbags in the management business. Most streets require a parking permit, but that's not expensive.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshman Housing Atmosphere – Being an RA, I've only lived in freshman dorms for all of college. But I love it.  The buildings themselves are not always the nicest or the prettiest, but there is an amazing sense of community in the freshman dorms.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Fair Market, but Do Your Research! There is a wide variety of options for off-campus housing in Pittsburgh, and prices are fairly reasonable.  CMU doesn't really provide any assistance for finding apartments.  My biggest suggestion is to DO YOUR RESEARCH!  There are a lot of slummy landlords out there, especially because of the number of college students looking for apartments in Pittsburgh.  Landorslum.com is a must before signing ANYTHING with a potential landlord.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are a ton of places to live off campus. Pittsburgh housing is pretty cheap too. The only down side is that once you are out of the school housing system its nearly impossible to get back in.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most Students Only Stay the First Year – The dorms on campus vary depending on the building. Morewood, Stever, and Mudge have nicer rooms. They're worth the extra couple of minutes to campus. Donner is slightly sub-par, but is conveniently in the heart of campus. Most dorms lack air conditioning, so be sure to pack a fan in the blazing first semester heat. Overall, I would guess about 80% of students move off campus after their freshman year. Pittsburgh has much more affordable apartments and houses that are just as close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Off Campus-Not Worth the Hastle – While off-campus housing is significantly cheaper than on-campus housing, they tend to be a 15-20 minute walk (sometimes more) and it becomes even more of a hastle during the winter. Many students who live off campus also feel the need for a car, which can turn out to be expensive, especially if you pay for campus parking. Another down side to off-campus housing, is that once you go off-campus, you can never apply for on-campus housing again--which is bad news if for some reason you can't continue living in the house.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman Dorms Are Definitely the Best – Most freshman dorms are right on campus or just across the street, except for the apartments, and the facilities are alright at best. I might be biased because it was my freshman dorm, but Morewood Gardens E-Tower is the best. We are right across the street from campus and we have our own dining vendor downstairs so we don't have to leave to eat. Also, our facilities are cleaned every weekday. The cost is definitely not as bad as other private colleges of CMU caliber. Most college housing is conveniently close to campus. Housing off-campus is much cheaper although it is must farther to walk to campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Like everywhere, there are bad landlords, so the trick is just doing research in order to find a decent one.  Plenty of good housing is available to those who seek it.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Average College Housing – The dorms are okay. They tend to either be older dorms with big rooms, or newer dorms with smaller rooms. Many of the dorms have a workout room and computer clusters inside, which is nice when the weather gets bad.
Housing.Author: College Freshman
